sections.title: QBH MAT Assessment, Update and Clinical Summary.policy  DRAFT 6 20 17

subpolicies.title: POLICY: MAT ASSESSMENTS, UPDATES AND CLINICAL SUMMARIES POLICY

blocks.text: The purpose of an assessment is to determine treatment eligibility, develop a treatment plan, and establish a measure for the response to treatment. For all applicants initially deemed eligible for medication-assisted treatment, designated, qualified program staff members complete a comprehensive physical examination, laboratory workup as indicated, psychosocial assessment, preliminary treatment plan, and consumer orientation during the initial treatment stage. Other assessments may also be ordered based upon screen results that trigger then need or based upon professional judgment or medical order.  As a consumer progresses through treatment, their status and indicated changes in treatment approach will be reviewed and assessments updated, as indicated, on a regular basis.  The clinical summary shall summarize the consumer’s status from a holistic perspective at least at admission, at review points and at discharge from treatment.

subpolicies.title: GENERAL GUIDELINES APPLICABLE TO ALL ASSESSMENTS

blocks.text: The battery of assessments is comprehensive and covers, minimally, based upon the consumer’s needs and condition: medical, psychosocial, vocational, educational, behavioral, family, financial, legal, health and self-care needs.
Rehab, education, and other counseling services are not required for consumers receiving interim maintenance treatment only.

Assessments shall be completed with each consumer at admission intake or within timeframes as set forth in this policy.  All required assessments must have been completed within 30 days of admission or less, if feasible.
Integrated Assessment: Part I is completed by the consumer during intake, with assistance of the Counselor.
Integrated Assessment:  Part II is completed by the Nurse (Nursing Assessment)

Integrated Assessment: Part III is completed by the Counselor as part of the initial intake appointment.   This assessment must include, minimally for MAT consumers, psychosocial, vocational, educational, current/historical behavioral/emotional functioning, family, financial, transportation status, legal, health and self-care needs, and screens for pain, nutritional issues, safety, and suicidal/homicidal issues.

Physical Examination is completed and signed by the physician within 24 hours of intake.   Telemedicine may not be used for this exam but may be used to support the decision making of a physician when a provider qualified to conduct the physical exam and make diagnoses is physically located with the consumer.

Psychiatric Evaluation is completed by the physician/psychiatrist when the physician doing their physical evaluation determines it is needed or their personal psychiatrist requests it, or by Counselor request.  It is completed within 72 hours of an order for the evaluation.
Initial Lab Analysis and Diagnostic Evaluation is part of the admission process and may include any of the following that are relevant to the consumer’s medical status:
Vital signs, including blood pressure, pulse, respiration, and temperature
Assess for symptoms of and risk factors for torsade’s de pointes and any follow-up tests
Drug screening for opiates, methadone, amphetamines, cocaine, marijuana, benzodiazepines, and other substances if indicated by individual consumer circumstances and local drug use patterns
Take temperature
Screen for syphilis
CBC and lipid panel
Liver function tests and viral hepatitis marker tests
HIV testing and counseling
Tests appropriate for screening or confirmation of illnesses or conditions based on concerns specific to the consumer regarding renal function, electrolyte imbalances, metabolic syndromes, pain, etc.
Pregnancy test
Neurological or psychological testing and assessment
Tb test and chest x-ray if skin test is positive
EKG
Pap smear
Screening for sickle cell disease
Additional tests based on results of baseline screens, especially when the results potentially impact treatment decisions
PHQ 9 shall be completed at admission by the consumer, and then repeated every 90 days by the consumer. during the full course of treatment.

Other Assessments, if indicated, will be completed and/or referred to the appropriate contractor or external resource for completion.  Transport for these assessments will be provided by QBH if needed.

A nutritional screen that reveals a weight gain or loss of 10 pounds or more over the past three months, a noticeable change in appetite, dental problems, noncompliance with a special diet, or food allergies shall trigger a full nutritional assessment.

A pain screen that reveals constant pain more than a 5 on a 0-10 pain scale, has not been evaluated or treated, is interfering with ADL capabilities or job/school performance shall trigger a full assessment by referral.
A risk screen that reveals moderate or high risk for suicide/homicide shall trigger a full risk assessment.
When indicated, the following evaluations may also be conducted by qualified staff or by referral: psychological, intellectual/cognitive functioning
All assessments shall remain in the medical record.

All assessments shall be conducted by qualified staff that has demonstrated that they are knowledgeable to assess the specific needs of consumers served, has been trained in use of the forms/tools involved, and has demonstrated skill in communicating with the consumer population served.

Diagnosis(es) derived from assessments may only be made by the assigned counselor or the physician.  If there is a discrepancy in diagnosis(es) arrived at by either of these staff, they shall discuss the differences and come to consensus.  If consensus is not achieved, the physician’s diagnosis(es) shall stand.
The problems identified from all assessments shall be listed on the Master Needs List and prioritized for treatment.

All assessments shall be conducted in the primary language of the consumer.  When a consumer is to complete a form, it shall be translated into his/her primary language.  All assessments entered into the medical record shall be accompanied by an English translation if originally completed in another language.  If a translator or technological assistance is needed, arrangement will be made to provide for this need.
The consumer being admitted to treatment is the primary source for provision of assessment information.  If the consumer has a legal guardian, this person will also contribute to the assessment.
Family or significant others contribution to the assessment is encouraged but is done only with written informed consent for information release and at the request of the consumer.
When relevant to the consumer’s care or services, the Counselor will gather behavioral and physical health information from both inpatient and outpatient providers who have treated the consumer.

If information is needed from other collateral sources such as the PCP, another provider, the outpatient case manager or social worker, the consumer’s employer, or a parole or probation officer, the Counselor will contact those sources only after receiving written informed consent for release of information from the consumer or their legal guardian, when applicable, unless such contact is legally mandated with or without consumer consent.
When it is not possible to obtain this information, the Counselor documents the reason why it could not be obtained.
The purpose of the assessments is to learn the consumer’s specific needs so that treatment can be personalized.
Assessments shall be completed as soon as possible, but always within at least 30 days of intake.
Assessments are signed and dated by the team member completing each.
Assessments shall identify the consumer’s personal short- and long-term goals and expectations of treatment as captured in their own words.

Assessment tools and treatment process are designed to be sensitive in identifying significant life or status changes of the consumer and to be responsive to the changing needs of the consumer.  Reassessment for changing needs and adjustment of treatment to meet changing needs is an ongoing process with each consumer encounter during treatment.
Assessments are formally updated and documented quarterly during the patient’s first year of continuous treatment and semiannually during subsequent years.  [CTS.02.02.07, EP 2]
Drug testing of consumers in the MAT program are conducted on an ongoing basis in compliance with MI state laws and following Company protocol.

Consumers in interim maintenance treatment experience urine screening upon admission and at least two more additional times if the consumer remains for the maximum 120 days permitted for interim treatment.
The consumer’s counselor determines the ongoing drug-testing regime of a given consumer by analyzing individual circumstances, the consumer’s stage of treatment, and community drug use patterns.

The counselor discusses results of toxicology testing promptly with the consumer and documents both the results of the toxicology tests and the follow-up therapeutic interventions discussed with the consumer in the consumer’s clinical record.

The clinical team intervenes when a consumer disclosed illicit drug use, has a positive drug test, or is suspected of diversion of opioid medication as evidenced by a lack of opioids or related metabolites in their drug toxicology tests. [CTS.02.02.09, EP 7,8,9,10,13]
Assessment results are communicated to the consumer and/or legal guardian at the end of the intake process and during treatment planning activities.
As indicated for treatment implementation and coordination, other staff making up the treatment team may be informed of assessment results.

If information needs to be shared with family or collateral sources such as the PCP, another provider, the outpatient case manager or social worker, the consumer’s employer, or a parole or probation officer, the Counselor will contact those sources only after receiving written informed consent for release of information from the consumer or their legal guardian, when applicable, unless such contact is legally mandated with or without consumer consent.

If a consumer has been in MAT services in the past year, the Bureau does not require that assessments be repeated at re-admission; however, QBH repeats the assessments if the interim since prior treatment has been at least six months, even though there are no reimbursements.  Even when regulation or policy does not require a new assessment, the latest assessments are nonetheless reviewed for any needed updates at every admission if the 6 month or 1-year timeframe has not triggered a new assessment series.

The staff conducting the various assessments gathers and documents adequate information during assessments to provide a complete picture of the consumer so that a comprehensive, consumer-centered plan can be developed.  Minimally, assessments collectively capture information regarding:
The consumer’s presenting issues and treatment goals in their own words, and those of the family when indicated and available.  [CTS.02.01.03, EP 3]
Identification of urgent needs associated with suicidal risk, personal safety and/or risk to others;
If suicidal risk is high, the consumer may be transported to a crisis intervention program; otherwise, a Safety Plan is developed with the consumer and risk is monitored till no longer present.
If personal safety risk is high, a Safety Plan is developed with the consumer and, if indicated, appropriate reporting to agencies associated with abuse or neglect will be notified.

If a risk to others is highly suspected or imminent, the staff identifying this risk shall immediately notify the CEO or designee AND the staff to notify both the at-risk party directly and notify a Safety Officer of the Police Department.
Personal strengths, individual limitations or needs, and personal abilities, leisure/recreation interests and preferences;

Previous diagnosis and treatment history, including what the consumer felt was and was not helpful in past treatment experiences; also, to include any complementary/alternative health approaches instead of, or in addition to, conventional medical treatment;
Current mental status;
Medication history and current use profile, including the efficacy of current or previously used medication and any known medication allergies or adverse reactions;

Physical health information, including current and past health needs, any co-occurring disabilities/disorders/medical conditions, current pregnancy status (if applicable, including notation of any prenatal care), and current level of psychological/social adjustment to these, and current level of health function in activities of daily living and self-care capabilities;  the physical exam includes, in addition to routine elements, a determination of the presence of clinical signs of addiction such as old or fresh needle marks, constricted or dilated pupils, and/or an eroded or perforated nasal septum, and dermatologic sequelae of addiction such as abscesses or presence and condition of tattoos and body piercings, as well as observable and reported presence of withdrawal symptoms, such as, yawning, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, chills, restlessness, irritability, perspiration, piloerection, nausea and diarrhea. Additionally, the consumer’s medical and family history to determine chronic or acute medical conditions such as, but not exclusively, diabetes; renal and/or pulmonary disease; chronic cardiopulmonary disease or cardiac abnormalities; and a series of infectious diseases such as hepatitis A, B, C and D; HIV exposure; Tb; STDs and other infectious diseases prevalent in the area or with the drug culture; sickle-cell trait or anemia; surgical problems; pregnancy (history and current, including prenatal care involvement); for evidence of physical pain; and psychiatric conditions meriting a psychiatric evaluation.

Consumers identified with physical pain will be referred for a physical pain assessment and for treatment of the physical pain at a pain management clinic.  Coordination with the pain management clinic and MAT program will occur to manage the treatment of both the chronic pain disorder and addiction; the consumer will receive their regular opioid medication at adequate doses to treat the addiction.   [CTS.02.01.09, EP 2,4,5]
Consumers testing positive for viral hepatitis receive a referral for further evaluation and treatment.
Consumers are immunized, or referred for immunization, against hepatitis A and B if not already immune and against other viral hepatitis strains as vaccines become available

The health screen or physical exam shall screen for nutritional issues and, the following information, at a minimum shall trigger a full nutritional assessment, either by a qualified staff within the Company or by referral:
Food allergies that are not being managed
Weight loss or gain of ten pounds or more in the last 3 months
Decrease in food intake and/or appetite
Unmanaged dental problems
Eating habits or behaviors that may be indicators of an eating disorder, such as binging or inducing vomiting

As relevant to consumer care and treatment, current and historical life situation information, including age, gender and sexual orientation/gender expression; cultural and spiritual identity and preferences, childhood and family history and current family circumstances, legal involvement, education and employment/vocational history, military history, language preference, current living situation, and availability of relationships/need for support systems within their family, friends, community or other interested parties, current resources tapped as needed;  [CTS.02.02.01, EP 3] Make sure there are prompts in one of your assessment tools for these elements if they are not already included.  I don’t have access to your assessment tools to make these changes.  Staff will need to be informed of these and any other policy/form changes before survey.

Educational status assessment shall include: educational background, academic performance and preferred areas of study, attitude toward academic achievement, possibilities for future education [CTS.02.04.01, EP 3] Make sure these prompts are on the tool that assesses education.

The consumer’s legal status assessment includes the following: legal history; preliminary discussion to determine how much the individual’s legal situation will influence their progress in care, treatment, or services, and the urgency of the legal situation; relationship between the presenting conditions and legal involvement.  [ CTS.02.01.15, EP3] Make sure these prompts are included in the tool that assesses legal status.
If a vocational assessment is indicated, based on the consumer’s needs, preferences, interests, and goals, they will be referred for such assessment. [CTS.02.01.17, EP1]
Trauma history, past or present, whether experienced or witnessed, including abuse, neglect, violence, or sexual assault, or exploitation;
Risk taking behaviors, current and past;
Alcohol, tobacco and/or another drug use, or other addictive behaviors as a primary or co-occurring condition(s) by the consumer and/or family members;

The addictions history for alcohol use, drug use, nicotine use, and other addictive behavior shall include at least: age of onset, method of acquisition of substance(s), duration of use, patterns of use (e.g., continuous, episodic, binge), frequency/amounts/tour of use of the substance taken, any mental/emotional/behavioral/legal, social consequences of the addiction (e.g., legal problems, divorce, loss of family/friends, job-related incidences, financial difficulties, blackouts, memory impairment), physical problems associated with the addiction, family addiction history, readiness to change, any spiritual perceptions/beliefs they perceive can aid their recovery/life. Also assessed is previous care/treatment, relapse history, and acute intoxication and/or withdrawal potential. [CTS.02.03.07, EP 1,2,3] Review appropriate assessment tool for whether all this is prompted…add if not.
Literacy level and any need for assistive technology as these impact services to be provided;
The presence of medical and/or psychiatric advance directives and/or interest in education on these matters
From assessment data, the Counselor and/or Physician should arrive at and document current diagnostic impressions.

subpolicies.title: Special Assessment Needs of Pregnant and Postpartum Consumers

blocks.text: These consumers are given priority for admission into MAT; the intake log shall document clearly the reasons for any admission denial of this consumer category.

Pregnant consumers receiving MAT treatment are informed that their infant that is prenatally exposed to opioids may experience neonatal abstinence syndrome, characterized by hyperactivity of the central and autonomic nervous systems reflected in changes in the GI tract and respiratory system; that symptoms may begin any time from birth to two weeks later, but usually within 72 hours; and that infants with this syndrome may engage in frantic sucking behaviors and difficulty feeding.  They are encouraged to seek comprehensive evaluation and treatment for the infant because other serious conditions can also mimic neonatal abstinence syndrome that require prompt treatment.

For those pregnant consumers without prenatal care, the consumer is referred to an appropriate provider with whom the Company has an agreement for services and a Business Associate agreement in compliance with HIPAA requirements.   Ongoing exchange of information between the prenatal care provider and the program physician is imperative to the consumer’s safety.
If the consumer refuses or cannot afford prenatal care, basic prenatal instruction is at least provided by the MAT program staff.

If the consumer refuses prenatal care, they shall sign a document that confirms they were offered a referral for the care and that they refused; the signed document is retained in the consumer’s record.

If a pregnant consumer is discharged, the program staff identifies the physician to whom the person served is being discharged. The program staff records the name, address, and telephone number of the physician who will be caring for the consumer after discharge.
Pregnant consumers in MAT treatment with concurrent HIV infection are managed in the same fashion as any other HIV infected consumer receiving MAT treatment.

These consumers are informed that HIV medication treatment is currently recommended to reduce perinatal transmission and provided with appropriate referral and case management to obtain that treatment.
The MAT program supports the decision to breast-feed during methadone treatment, unless medically contraindicated, for example, by the presence of HIV or HTLV I or II infection in the mother.

The MAT program staff shall document appropriate counseling and informed decision-making between provider and consumer to see that issues mentioned in the latest consumer information sheets and product inserts for methadone are covered and understood.

The staff obtains informed consent to provide for appropriate follow-up and primary care for the new mother and well-baby care for the infant. Informed consent refers to the patient’s agreement to receive treatment as well as agreement to release information to and obtain information from pertinent health care providers.

Upon completion of all the intake related assessments, the assigned Counselor is responsible to review all the assessment data and to generate a Clinical Integrated Summary of Findings that integrates all of the facts gathered during assessment(s) into a picture of the dynamics at play in the consumer’s reason for seeking treatment, i.e., substance abuse.
Completion is by the assigned Counselor by the second appointment.
The summary contains at least four basic elements to be complete.  These are:

A brief description of the consumer’s demographics that includes their age, gender, ethnic/cultural propensities that impact treatment approach, and whether this is their first or repeated treatment experience for substance abuse.

The “picture” – a description of the pre-existing and/or influencing factors (social, emotional/psychological, and physical) that are interacting either causally or as a reaction/result of the substance abuse.  Co-occurring disabilities, co-morbidities and/or disorders are identified
A description of the assets or strengths the consumer brings to treatment that may be used or drawn from to establish treatment objectives.

A description of the effects of this dynamic interplay.  That is, the barriers or treatment needs that will need re-focus or where the consumer will need assistance to resolve or reduce their substance abuse and move toward recovery.
The Clinical Integrated Summary of Findings is utilized in formulating the personalized treatment plan.
Each treatment review is an opportunity to discuss how these dynamics have changed as a result of treatment to date and/or as a result of new information assessed.

The Discharge Summary contains the last and final opportunity to discuss how these dynamics have changed as a result of treatment.  (Often referred to in the Discharge Summary as “consumer’s condition or status at discharge.”)
Each of these summaries should mirror the Master Needs List at that time and visa- versa…what is mentioned in one should be reflected in the other, thus creating a check and balance system.

sections.title: QBH MAT Behavior Management Special Procedures.policy    FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: No treatment interventions shall be utilized which are intended to elicit fear, pain, humiliation or which involve the use of corporal punishment.  Nutrition may not be denied as part of behavior management planning; nor shall food be used as a positive reinforcer.  No behavioral management techniques related to sleeping or toileting shall be used.
Behavioral management shall be directed towards increasing positive and pro-social peer and authority figure interactions rather than behavioral control alone.
Behavioral redirection and usual de-escalation techniques will be used if the consumer(s) cannot re-gain self-control on their own or by reminder or verbal/visual prompt.

The consumer(s) is encouraged to identify an appropriate action for handling the situation and to initiate that action; the goal is to help the consumer feel empowered to personally gain control of behavior rather than requiring outside intervention.
Staff will assist the consumer in processing an appropriate action if needed.
If a consumer is unable to control behavior without consequences despite staff assistance, any of the following interventions might be utilized depending upon the situation:
Voluntary Time Out Intervention

Time out does not require a physician order and may be used as an intervention if contained within the PTP.  An assessment of the appropriateness and outcome of using time out will be reflected in the Progress Notes.
Procedure for implementing time out shall be:

The staff will make a verbal request, in a calm and non-threatening manner, to the consumer to cooperate with staff, to take self-control and to walk, on their own accord, to the designated time out area (area must be free of potentially dangerous objects and non-lockable).

If the consumer agrees, two staff shall walk on either side of the consumer to the time out area.  The time out area shall be away from other activity and persons but within view of a designated staff member.
The consumer, once in the time out area, will be informed that they are being given fifteen minutes to gain control and that a staff member will then return to process the previous events with them.
If, when the staff member returns to process, the consumer is still not enough in control to process, an additional fifteen minutes shall be granted before processing.

After the fifteen or thirty minutes, the staff shall process with the consumer.  The consumer is allowed to leave the time out area when they are able to identify what behavior was inappropriate and what they should do differently if the situation occurs again.
911 Call
If a consumer’s behavior escalates to a level of potential or actual violence (i.e., physically assaultive to self, others, or staff), persons in the immediate area should be removed immediately.
A staff should position themselves where they can see the consumer but not be near them or in a location where the consumer blocks their exit from the area.
Simultaneously, someone should be directed to call 911 for immediate intervention and removal from the facility.
When law enforcement officials arrive they shall take charge of the consumer; they shall not bring firearms into the facility.
The CEO and Clinical Director should be notified as soon as possible after the 911 call.

A Progress Note is written describing the incident, who was involved, what efforts to help the consumer gain control were used and the consumer’s response, when the 911 call was placed and what transpired until law enforcement arrived and once they arrived.
An Incident Report should be written and submitted to the Quality Manager within 24 hours of the incident.
Seclusion and restraint are not utilized in any of QBH’s MAT program.
The following hospital agreements exist for accepting of consumers with a psychiatric emergency:
William Beaumont Hospital – Sterling Heights
All staff with direct care roles shall be trained in de-escalation techniques.  Re-training shall occur at least annually.

Incident Report
Progress Note

sections.title: QBH MAT Bloodborne Pathogens.policy   FINAL R 11 12

blocks.text: QBH staff will comply with the OSHA and CDC guidelines for workplace controls of bloodborne pathogens.

Emergencies involving blood or other potentially infectious materials including urine, feces, semen, vaginal secretions and all body fluids in situations where it is difficult or impossible to differentiate between body fluids will be managed utilizing strict body substance precautions (universal precautions).

According to the concept of universal precautions, these fluids are treated as if known to be infectious for HIV, HBV, and other bloodborne pathogens. Work practice controls means controls that reduce the likelihood of exposure by altering the manner in which a task in performed.
Job classifications in which all staff has potential for occupational exposure:
Social Workers/Counselors
Physicians/Psychiatrists
Monitors
Clerical Support
List of tasks and procedures in which occupational exposure occurs and that are performed by staff in job classifications listed:
Job Classification	Task/Procedure
Psychiatrist/Physician	Examinations
All staff	Cleaning spill of potentially infectious body fluids
Universal precautions shall be utilized to prevent contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials. All blood and other potentially infectious materials will be considered infectious.

Work practice controls will be used to eliminate or minimize staff exposure. Where exposure remains after institution of these controls, personal protective equipment will also be used. At this Agency the following engineering controls will be utilized: gloves, gowns, goggles/protective eyewear, sharps containers.
Eating, drinking, smoking, applying cosmetics and handling contact lenses are prohibited in work areas where there is a reasonable likelihood of occupational exposure.
Hand washing facilities are readily accessible to staff. At this Agency, hand washing sinks are located in all bathrooms and in the staff room.  (see Hand Washing Policy)
Staff will wash their hands immediately after removal of gloves with soap and water.

Staff will wash their hands and any other skin with soap and water or flush mucous membranes (eyes, mouth) with water immediately following contact of specific body areas, blood, or other body fluids.
Staff will use appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) at all times.
P.P.E. will be readily accessible in the Front Office and will be replaced as needed to maintain its effectiveness.

Gloves will be worn when it can be reasonably anticipated that the staff may have contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials, (i.e. feces, vomit, urine, etc.), and when handling or touching contaminated items or surfaces.
Gloves will not be washed or re-used. Used gloves and any contaminated items will be disposed of in appropriate Hazmat containers.
Gloves will be used for the following procedures:
All housekeeping tasks
Cleaning wet spills of potentially infectious fluids

subpolicies.title: HEPATITIS B VACCINATION AND POST-EXPOSURE EVALUATION AND FOLLOW-UP

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. will make available the hepatitis B vaccine to all staff that has an occupational exposure incident, and post-exposure evaluation and follow-up to all staff that has had an exposure incident at no cost to the staff.
All staff is encouraged to get hepatitis vaccinations prior to employment.
When a staff member incurs an exposure incident it will be reported immediately via the procedure for Incident Reports.
Following a report of an exposure incident the CEO will make immediately available to the exposed staff a confidential medical evaluation through the person’s primary care provider.
The CEO shall provide the following information to the health care professional evaluating the exposure incident:
A copy of this document.
A description of the exposed staff’s duties as they relate to the exposure incident.
Documentation of the route(s) of exposure and circumstances under which exposure occurred.
Vaccination status of the staff member.
The CEO will obtain and provide the staff member with a copy of the evaluating health care professional’s written opinion within 15 days of completion of the evaluation.
Post-exposure evaluation and follow up shall include:
Documentation of the route of exposure and the circumstances related to the incident.

If possible, the identification of the source individual and, if possible, the status of the source individual. The blood of the source individual will be tested for HIV/HBV infectivity following applicable laws and regulations.

Results of testing of the source individual will be made available to the exposed staff with the staff also being reminded about the applicable laws and regulations concerning disclosure of the identity and infectivity of the source individual.
The staff will be offered the options of having their blood collected for testing of HIV/HBV serological status.
The staff will be offered post exposure prophylaxis in accordance with the current recommendations.
The staff will be given appropriate counseling concerning precautions to take during the period immediately following the exposure incident including what potential illness’ to be alert for.
Interaction with Health Care Providers:
A written opinion will be obtained from the health care provider who evaluates QBH Inc. staff whenever the staff member is sent following an exposure incident.
Health Care providers will be instructed to limit their opinions to:
Whether the Hepatitis B vaccine is indicated and if the staff has received the vaccine or for evaluation following an incident.
That the staff has been informed of the results of the evaluation.
That the staff has been told about any medical conditions resulting from exposure. The written opinion is not to reference any personal medical information.
STAFF HEALTH RECORD
The Company will establish and maintain an accurate record for each staff with occupational exposure. This record will include:
The name and the social security number of the staff.
A copy of the staff’s hepatitis B vaccination status including the dates of all the hepatitis B vaccinations and any information relative to the staff’s ability to receive vaccination.
A copy of all results of examinations, medical testing, and follow-up procedures.
The Company’s copy of the healthcare professional’s written opinion.
A copy of the information provided to the healthcare professional.
Confidentiality shall be maintained of that staff’s medical information.  The information shall be:
Kept confidential.
Not disclosed or reported without the staff’s express written consent to any person within or outside the workplace except as required by this section or as may be required by law.
The Company shall maintain the records for at least the duration of employment plus 30 years in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.20.
Training records shall include the following information:
The dates of the training sessions;
The contents or a summary of the training sessions;
The names and qualifications of persons conducting the training; and
The names and job titles of all persons attending the training sessions.
Training for staff will include the following:
The OSHA standard for Bloodborne Pathogens.
Epidemiology and symptomatology of bloodborne diseases.
Modes of transmission of bloodborne pathogens.
This policy, i.e. points of the policy, lines of responsibility, how the policy will be implemented, etc.
Procedures which might cause exposure to blood or other potentially infectious materials at this Agency.
Control methods which will be used to control exposure to blood or other potentially infectious materials.
Personal protective equipment available
Who should be contacted concerning post exposure evaluation and follow-up.
Signs and labels used.
Hepatitis B vaccine advocacy by the Agency.
All staff will receive annual refresher training.
Training materials are located in the Nurses’ Office.
All records required by the OSHA standard will be maintained by the Safety Officer.

sections.title: QBH MAT Case Management and Service Coordination.policy FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: The counselor assigned to a consumer is primarily responsible for coordination of care delivered within QBH to consumers assigned to the counselor.  Such activities may also be assisted by a case manager, as appropriate.
Key areas of care coordination internal to QBH include, but not exclusively:
Overseeing full implementation of the consumer’s treatment plan.
Orientation of the consumer to the services s/he will be receiving.
Promoting the consumer’s participation in discussion of his/her plan, goals and status on an ongoing basis.
Identifying and addressing any gaps in service provision.
Sharing information on how to access other community resources relevant to the consumer’s needs.
Advocating for the consumer, when needed.
Communicating information regarding the consumer’s progress to appropriate persons.
Involving the family or legal guardian, when permitted.

When services or resources are needed to assist the consumer to meet their personalized treatment plan objectives that are not available within QBH’s MAT program, consumers are guided in identification and contact with outside services or resources.

The consumer’s assigned Counselor and/or case manager, if applicable, will coordinate, or assist the consumer to personally contact the service agency or other resource(s) needed to achieve their PTP objectives, when needed.
Counselors/case managers are knowledgeable of and/or can locate community services and resources available in the Macomb County areas, as appropriate to the location where they provide services.

Counselors/case managers place particular emphasis on identifying with the consumer whether they have sufficient support systems to sustain and move them forward in their recovery during and post-treatment and help the consumer to identify and select helpful resources to build that support, if lacking, prior to the consumer’s discharge.

Case management/service coordination is a joint effort of the counselor and/or case manager and the consumer; outside care may be arranged by the counselor/case manager after consumer input and agreement or arrangement may be made by the consumer with guidance from the counselor/case manager, if the consumer is able and willing.
The intensity of case management/service coordination is dependent upon the consumer’s needs as reflected in the PTP.
Referrals and follow-up for other health care related needs of the consumer in MAT are completed within 3 months of program admission.
The type(s) of services or resources are directed by the specific needs of the consumer.  They may include, but not exclusively:
Outreach to encourage the consumer’s participation.
Coordination or assistance with crisis intervention and stabilization services.
Consumers with identified mental health needs are referred to appropriate treatment, concurrent with MAT treatment.
Optimization of resources and opportunities through community linkages and enhanced social support networks.
Michigan Rehabilitation Services is used to assist consumers with education, employment, personal needs or activities of daily living.
DHS is used to assist with income, disability and food stamp and other financial needs
NA and/or AA 12 Step Recovery meetings and mutual help groups to assist with recovery progress
Local Medical Centers/Hospitals to assist with medical and other health care needs
Access to transportation.
Facilitating the transition process, including arrangements for follow-up services.
Coordinating any services provided outside of QBH.
Securing safe housing that fits the needs and abilities of the consumer.
Engagement in other meaningful activities to build community ties, support structures, and/or sustain recovery and well-being, etc.

Linkages for skill development such as budgeting, meal planning, personal care, housekeeping and home maintenance or other identified needs if not covered by QBH program didactics or if development beyond what is provided is needed.
Other community services, as needed by consumers.
Feedback is informally exchanged with outside organizations/agencies providing services to consumers only with the consumer’s permission.
All case management and service coordination activities are addressed in the Master Needs List, the PTP and in progress notes.
Consumers who are pregnant or parenting have special needs that must be addressed as a part of their MAT process.  Services either provided internally or by referral include:
Education about neonatal abstinence syndrome, its symptoms, its potential effect on their infants, and the need for treatment.
Assistance to obtain evaluation and treatment if their infant may be susceptible to neonatal abstinence syndrome.

Referral to parenting support groups or other children’s services, including referrals for services the child may need due to special mental and cognitive needs, especially if abuse or neglect has occurred.
Referrals for child care services.
Referral for parenting skills education, unless provided in the program.
Referral for prenatal care; reciprocity in the exchange of pertinent clinical information about compliance with the recommended medical care will be established as required by federal law.

If the pregnant consumer refuses direct or referred prenatal care, the program physician or designee has the consumer formally acknowledge in writing that the program offered or referred for those services but the consumer refused them.

If the pregnant consumer refuses direct or referred prenatal care, the program offers basic prenatal instruction on maternal, physical, and dietary care.  The education is documented in the consumer record.
Information and counsel to the pregnant consumer about the latest consumer information sheets and product inserts for methadone shall be documented in the consumer’s record.
Case management services are provided at QBH facilities where MAT programs are provided  in Sterling Heights, these areas highly populated by the types of citizens likely to need QBH’s MAT services.

sections.title: QBH MAT CONSUMER AND FAMILY INVOLVEMENT.policy   FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Involve consumers and their significant others in the assessment, treatment and service evaluation process to the extent feasible and appropriate.

It is QBH’s belief that consumers get sick and recover in the context of a social unit that either lends support to wellness or deters a wellness state; therefore, the most effective approach to service delivery is to provide it in the context of the whole consumer, including their social environment whenever possible.

subpolicies.title: CONSUMER AND FAMILY IPARTICIPATION IN SERVICE

blocks.text: The consumer and his/her significant others shall participate in all aspects of the service delivery process to the extent they are willing and that it is advisable to the consumer's condition.

The consumer shall not receive service unless and until s/he has been informed about the expectations and consequences of treatment and signs a written Consent to Treatment form. In the case of assigned guardianship, the guardian or legal representative shall sign this form.

The consumer and significant others, if appropriate, shall be informants during the assessment process. Assessment shall include documentation in the medical record, of the consumer's and significant others' expectations for treatment.
The consumer and significant others, if appropriate, shall participate in the development of the treatment plan and sign the plan as evidence of being informed and of their participation.
If they have any disagreement with the plan of treatment, the consumer's medical record shall so indicate and the assigned therapist shall mediate a solution to the conflict.
The consumer and significant others, if appropriate, shall also participate in each treatment plan review.

When appropriate, the consumer's significant others shall be included in his/her treatment
process through educational, marital, family, and/or support group therapy.
Family involvement is documented in the consumer’s medical record.

If a consumer's significant others are unable or unwilling to participate in the consumer's service delivery process as described  above, or such participation is clinically inappropriate, such circumstances shall be documented in the consumer's medical record. The assigned therapist will work with the consumer, as part of treatment, to develop a functional support system if that normally availed by significant others is unavailable and/or nonfunctional.

Consent to Treatment

sections.title: QBH MAT Consumer and Staff Infections.policy  FINAL 6 17

subpolicies.title: POLICY:    IDENTIFICATION OF CONSUMER AND STAFF INFECTION

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. (QBH) attempts to maintain a safe environment for consumers and staff.  One aspect of a safe environment is maintaining, as far as possible, an infection-free Company’s program. To that end, a surveillance system is required to identify infections in order to contain and/or eliminate them.

Healthcare acquired Infection – an infection that did not exist prior to the consumer’s admission to the Company’s program.  Data must exist that supports or confirms that the infection did not exist and was not incubating prior to admission. This does not apply to the MAT program since the program is outpatient in nature.

Community Acquired Infection – an infection that existed or was incubating prior to admission to the Company’s program.  Typically infections occurring within the first 24-48 hours of admission are community-acquired.
Communicable Disease – a disease that may be transmitted from one individual to another.
Identifying a Consumer Illness

If a consumer, while receiving treatment from QBH, reports feelings of illness, the staff member involved will document this occurrence in the medical record.  Guardians and other legally responsible persons shall be notified, in applicable.  All notifications shall also be entered into the clinical record.
Action of nursing staff in such instances is to assess the severity of illness with the assistance of a physician, if needed.  If an emergency exists, call 911 immediately.
Acute Illness

A nurse on duty will promptly evaluate a consumer who becomes physically ill while being treated at the MAT program. The consumer will be referred to their primary physician for evaluation, or will be transferred for emergency treatment, if the consumer’s condition indicates a need to do so.  If the consumer remains in treatment, the psychiatrist will determine the level of ongoing treatment during the course of physical illness.
Chronic, Non-communicable Illness or Physical Disability
Reasonable accommodation shall be made to facilitate treatment of chronically ill or physically disabled
consumers.  Accommodations may include adjustments to the physical environment, timing and/or 	frequency of treatment/interventions, and length of sessions according to consumer tolerance.
Communicable Illness

Consumers with known communicable illness that can be easily transmitted through normal social contact shall provide evidence of treatment (physician statement) before beginning or re-entering treatment.

When a consumer is discovered to have a communicable illness during treatment, the consumer will be referred immediately to their physician, or the County Health Department for treatment; Universal Precautions will be initiated as appropriate while the consumer remains at the Company’s program.

The nurse shall complete an Incident Report within 24 hours of discovery of the communicable illness.  This report shall be reviewed by the Infection Control Coordinator (ICC) to determine any follow-up action/investigation that may be indicated.
Surveillance of Consumer Infections
Selection of surveillance methodology
The Clinical Committee shall review and determine the surveillance methodology to be followed on an annual basis.
Criteria to be used by the committee in methodology selection include:
The risk factors within the consumer population.
Infection trends within the Company’s program population and endemic/epidemic in the community.
Incidence and or risk for infectious complication or adverse consumer outcomes within the consumer population.
Potential for prevention.
Surveillance methodology used at this Company’s program is Total Surveillance.  The surveillance approaches include:
A record of all infections occurring.
Problem-oriented or outbreak response.
Periodic visual survey of all the program areas with findings recorded on the Infection Control
Surveillance Form will be conducted.  The ICC will follow findings and need for corrective action.
Implementation
The ICC is responsible for coordinating surveillance activities, including data collection, evaluation, follow-
up,  and reporting.
The ICC shall be responsible to inform the appropriate public health authorities of any reportable infectious
disease identified through surveillance.
The ICC shall report communicable diseases subject to mandatory reporting requirements within 24
hours of diagnosis to the proper state or local health authorities.
The ICC shall maintain a current list of infections reportable to the Department of Health.
The ICC will keep a log of infections reported and review periodically from trends or patterns that may
support the need for infection control practice improvements.
Surveillance shall be conducted as follows:
All staff is responsible for reporting suspected consumer infection to the ICC.  To identify what constitutes a consumer illness, see the addendum to the Policy on Definition of Infections.
The ICC keeps a log of infections on the Infection Surveillance Log.
The ICC may recommend precautionary measures to staff and/or consumer.
The ICC shall follow-up as indicated to facilitate appropriate management of the infections condition within
the program setting.
The ICC shall track, trend and report the incidence of both healthcare acquired and community-acquired
infections, and when indicated, initiate focused studies in order to reduce or eliminate future breakouts or        clusters of infection.
HIV or AIDS and Consumers
Testing
Voluntary testing will be offered to all consumer of high-risk groups, and consumers who engage in
high-risk behaviors.
Voluntary testing will be facilitated upon request by the consumer and/or legal guardian.
Testing may be mandatory to determine risk to a victim after an attack, sexual assault, biting, etc.
Testing may be mandatory for any consumer who exhibits symptoms of ARC or AIDS. Test results will be

used to develop a diagnosis to provide appropriate care and treatment. Positive test results will be    reported to the Michigan State Department of Health by both the laboratory and Infection Control Coordinator.
The consumer or legal guardian, if applicable, shall be counseled prior to testing to explain the
procedure and possible results.
The consumer or legal guardian, if applicable, shall be counseled after the test to explain the results,
reporting requirements, and special precautions.
Treatment of Consumers with positive HIV status or AIDS

QBH is not a medical facility, nor a long term care facility, and shall not exceed its medical capability. It must first be established that the consumer is medically stable prior to admission.    The purpose of the admission must be based on SAMHSA criteria with the potential for placement elsewhere pending discharge.

Universal precautions and other infection control practices should be consistent with Hepatitis B guidelines as proposed by the Center for Disease Control at the time.  The ICC will provide education on current practices to the consumer and staff upon diagnosis.  This includes the use of gloves and hand washing in contact with blood or body fluid secretions.  Casual contact does not transmit AIDS.
Ability to provide medical care and treatment to ARC/AIDS consumers will be determined on an
individual basis.
Confidentiality
As with all other consumer information, a person’s HIV status will remain confidential and will only be
released per written request of consumer or as stated above, of this policy regarding notification of the    Michigan State Department of Health.
Surveillance of Staff Infections
Illness

Staff is expected to recognize the importance of not infecting others when they have a communicable disease.  Transmitting infections to others leads to lost time for the Company’s program and consumer treatment.
Staff that appears to be ill may be asked to go home by the CEO, ICC or Medical Director.

Any staff exposed to communicable diseases during the course of their employment will complete an Incident Report.  The Infection Control Coordinator will make appropriate referral for preventative treatment as indicated.  The staff’s physician or a Company program physician, if indicated, will determine final disposition.
Management may require a doctor’s work release prior to staff returning to work.
Injuries
Staff should report any injuries to the Clinical Director or Medical Director immediately.

Management may determine that some injuries will require a doctor’s work release before the staff may return to work.  Even with such a release, the Company’s CEO or designee may determine that allowing a staff to return to work puts the staff or others at risk, and will not allow the staff to return to work.
Surveillance of Infection
The Infection Control Coordinator is responsible for coordinating staff surveillance activities, including data collection, evaluation, follow-up, and reporting.
The ICC shall be responsible to inform the appropriate public health authorities of any reportable infectious
disease identified through surveillance.
Surveillance shall be conducted as follows:
The ICC shall keep a daily log of any staph infection on the Infection Surveillance Log (ISL).
The ICC shall review the ISL to gather epidemiological information and explore whether appropriate
precautions are being followed.
The ICC shall follow-up as needed to facilitate appropriate management of the infectious condition and
adjustment of work assignment, if indicated.
The ICC shall track, trend and report the incidence of infections, and, when indicated, initiate focused
studies in order to reduce or eliminate future breakouts or clusters of infection.

The CEO and ICC will determine the appropriateness of a staff member continuing to work if infectious.  Decisions will be made on an individual basis.  At times, the staff member may be required to bring a physician’s release before work attendance can resume.
AIDS:  Staff of QBH with AIDS, when asymptomatic, will be considered on an individual basis through HR in cooperation with the staff member’s private physician to determine if:
They are free from transmissible infection.
They are not unduly susceptible to infections that they might come in contact with at work.

The staff member that believes they are at high risk for infection because of their own immune status should discuss this problem with their own personal physician.  If the physician determines that there are certain assignments that they should not accept, this shall be communicated in writing to HR.  This information will be forwarded to the CEO.  These policies apply to all staffs with communicable or life threatening diseases.
All staff will be afforded the highest degree of confidentiality.
Referral sources will be made for counseling and medical care, if indicated.
Staff will follow guidelines in regard to sick leave and Worker’s Compensation.

The Infection Control Coordinator will evaluate, review, and, if needed, revise the policy annually (once a year every 12 months plus or minus thirty days) and submit to the Clinical Committee for approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT Consumer Contraband.policy  FINAL 7 17

blocks.text: The following is a list of items which are considered contraband, and which are not permitted on the grounds of QBH or a QBH sponsored activity:
Weapons of any kind, or objects which are adaptable to be used as weapons.
Illegal drugs or alcohol. Legally prescribed medications must be in the original packaging and in the possession of a responsible adult.
Sexually explicit materials in written, electronic, or other form.
Inhalable substances, such as aerosol spray cans and toxic glues or paints.

Drug paraphernalia, including but not limited to: pipes, rolling papers, syringes (unless verified as medically appropriate and in the possession of a responsible adult), and clothing or other objects with explicit drug images or messages.
Tattooing devices.
Spray paint and/ or permanent markers, except as approved by a QBH MAT program staff member.
Other objects or substances not listed above may be deemed contraband if determined by QBH MAT program staff to pose a significant risk of harm to consumers, visitors, or staff.

Contraband is subject to being confiscated by QBH MAT program staff if brought onto QBH’s property or a QBH sponsored event.  Any illegal substances or illegal objects such as weapons shall be destroyed or turned over to legal authorities.  Contraband that does not fall into the category of illegal may be returned to the consumer or the consumer’s legal guardian when the consumer leaves the QBH MAT program premises, at the discretion of a program staff member.

QBH MAT program staff shall not retain any item of contraband, including tobacco products, for their own use.  All contraband must be destroyed, returned to the consumer/guardian, or turned over to law enforcement.

Any contraband to be destroyed must be destroyed in the presence of at least two staff persons and according to Federal guidelines and documented in the consumer’s medical record as such.  Substances or chemicals (such as prescription medications, marijuana, etc.) will be dissolved, if possible, and then mixed with an undesirable substance, such as used coffee grounds or kitty litter, placed in a sealed bag, and then placed in the garbage, or using other state-of-the-art methods approved by the CEO.

Discovery of contraband shall warrant the writing of an Incident Report by the QBH MAT program staff member.  The Incident Report shall be routed internally and/or externally, dependent upon the nature of the contraband and the mandates of the licensing authority and contractual agreements with other agencies and government entities.
The Clinical Director will review this policy annually, and the Clinical Committee will review and approve.

sections.title: QBH MAT CONSUMER HYGIENE.policy   FINAL 62017

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. (QBH) will sustain an active hygiene program in all QBH's Programs.
If a consumer is identified as having hygiene issues, the problem will be addressed in their treatment plan, identifying appropriate objectives and interventions.
If there is a significant trend in hygiene issues, a life skill group may be initiated to address this health concern.

subpolicies.title: POLICY:    DEFINITIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS OF INFECTION

blocks.text: The Infection Control Coordinator (ICC) will use definitions developed by the Center for Disease Control (CDC).  The ICC will review these definitions annually and revise as recommended by the CDC and approved by the Infection Control function of the Clinical Committee.

Healthcare Acquired Infection: An infection that did not exist prior to the patient’s admission to the Organization.  Data must exist that supports or confirms that the infection did not exist and was not incubating prior to admission.

Community Acquired Infection – an infection that existed or was incubating prior to admission to the Company’s program.  Typically infections occurring within the first 24-48 hours of admission are community-acquired.
Communicable Disease – a disease that may be transmitted from one individual to another
PRINCIPLES USED IN DEFINITIONS FOR SURVEILLANCE OF HEALTHCARE ACQUIRED INFECTIONS (Not applicable to consumers in MAT program)
For an infection to be defined as healthcare acquired, there must be no evidence that the infection was present or incubating at the time of admission.

Information to be used to determine the presence and classification for an infection involves various combinations of clinical findings and results of laboratory and other diagnostic tests.  Clinical evidence is derived from direct observation of the patient and/or review of information in the patient chart, i.e., temperature.  Laboratory evidence consists of results of cultures, antigen or antibody detection, and supportive data derived from x-ray studies.

A physician’s diagnosis of infection derived from direct observation, other diagnostic study, or based on clinical judgment are acceptable criteria for an infection unless there is compelling evidence to the contrary; i.e., information on the wrong patient’s record or a presumptive diagnosis that was not substantiated by subsequent studies.

Except for a few situations that are referred to in the definitions, no specific time during or after admission is given to determine whether an infection is healthcare acquired or community-acquired due to the varied incubation periods of disease.  Thus each infection must be assessed for evidence that links it to the stay in the Organization.
Infection that is associated with a complication or extension of infection(s) already present on admission, unless a change in pathogen or symptoms strongly suggests the acquisition of new infection.
Infection identified within the first 24-48 hours after admission.

sections.title: QBH MAT EXPOSURE CONTROL.policy   FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: It is the expectation of Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. (QBH) that all staff shall practice in compliance with infection control standards and regulations and with Organization policies. Treatment and/or emergencies involving blood or other potentially infectious materials including urine, feces, semen, vaginal secretions and all body fluids in situations where it is difficult or impossible to differentiate between body fluids will be managed utilizing strict body substance precautions (universal precautions). According to the concept of universal precautions, these fluids are treated as if known to be infectious for HIV, HBV, Coronavirus, and other blood borne pathogens.

One of the important goals of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) is to promote safe work precautions in an effort to minimize the incidence of the illness and injury experienced by the staff.   In accordance with the OSHA blood borne pathogens standard, the following exposure control policy has been developed.
Work practice controls: means controls that reduce the likelihood of exposure by altering the manner in which a task in performed.

Bloodborne pathogens: pathogenic microorganisms that are present in human blood and cause disease in humans.  They include but are not limited to, Hepatitis B virus, (HBV), and Human Immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

Exposure control:  A system to control or minimize the spread of bloodborne pathogens using universal precautions as well as personal protective equipment. Exposure control has checks and balances and cooperation of all departments.
Standard Precautions/Universal precautions: an approach to infection control designed to prevent transmission of blood-borne diseases such as AIDS, hepatitis B in health care settings.

Personal protective equipment: Equipment used to assist in containment of infectious disease as well as protect the staff from infection. The guidelines for universal precautions include specific recommendations for the use of gloves, masks, and protective eyewear when contact with blood or body secretions containing blood is anticipated.

The following are suggested general principles that should be followed when working with bloodborne pathogens. The risk of exposure to bloodborne pathogens should never be underestimated and universal precautions should be followed when working with bloodborne pathogens.
It is necessary to minimize all exposure to bloodborne pathogens.

QBH will institute universal precautions using personal protective equipment as well as engineering and work practice controls when possible to eliminate or minimize staff exposure to bloodborne pathogens.
An Exposure Control Plan has been implanted to meet the intent of the OSHA Bloodborne Pathogen Standards.  The object of this plan is two-fold:
To protect staff from health hazards associated with bloodborne pathogens.
To provide appropriate treatment and counseling should an staff be exposed to bloodborne pathogens.

Nurse/Psychiatrist /Physician                           Administering injections
Nurse/Behavioral Health Technician/          	   Cleaning spills of potentially infectious secretions
Housekeeping                                                      Secretions / handling laundry
A method to minimize exposure to bloodborne pathogens (refer to methods of compliance policy).
Universal precautions shall be utilized to prevent contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials. All blood and other potentially infectious materials will be considered infectious.

The practice of Universal Precautions was instituted to minimize contact with blood and other body fluids. As a result, all human blood, and body fluids are treated as if they are infected with HBV, HIV, and other bloodborne pathogens.
Personal protective equipment as part of Universal precautions will be utilized to prevent contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials.

Personal protective equipment (PPE) is the staff’s “last line of defense” against bloodborne pathogens.  This is because, the organization provides (at no cost to the staff), personal protective equipment needed to protect the staff from such exposure.
Single use PPE is the only equipment QBH uses and past each use the PPE will be disposed in the correct manner.
Personal Protective Equipment includes but is not limited to the following:
Gowns
Gloves
Aprons
Goggles
Face shields/masks
Disposal Mouthpieces to be used in CPR
Booties – shoe covers
Hair covering
Resuscitation bags

The Infection Control Coordinator, working with Administration and other designees, is 			 responsible for overseeing that all departments have the proper personal protective equipment 			 available to them. The ICC is also responsible for the initial, annual and as needed training 			 regarding Personal Protective Equipment.
The ICC along with department managers are responsible to see that all PPE is inspected 			 periodically and replaced as needed to maintain its effectiveness.
The following practices will be implemented when using Personal Protective Equipment.
Staff will use appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE), i.e. gloves, tissues, etc. at all times.  PPE
will be readily accessible in the Medication Room, in a visible location on each unit, in each vehicle that 	transports consumers, and will be replaced as needed to maintain its effectiveness.

Gloves will be worn when it can be reasonably anticipated that the staff may have contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials, (i.e. feces, vomit, urine, etc.), and when handling or touching contaminated items or surfaces. Gloves will not be washed or re-used.  Gloves must be used for the following procedures:
Injections and other invasive procedures
All housekeeping tasks
Cleaning wet spills of potentially infectious fluids
Handling contaminated laundry
Gloves will be worn in the following situations:

When handling or touching contaminated items or surfaces, or when a staff anticipates hand contact with potentially infectious materials. Disposal gloves will be replaced when torn, punctured or when the gloves otherwise lose their ability to function as an “exposure barrier”.
Hypoallergenic gloves will be provided to staff that are allergic to Latex or are allergic to the gloves that Pronghorn Psychiatry provides.
Masks, face shields, goggles, etc will be used whenever splashes or sprays from blood borne materials may occur.
Shoe covers and hair covering, will be worn whenever a “gross contamination” is anticipated or noted.
Protective clothing will be worn whenever a potential exposure to the body is anticipated.
Goggles and/or gown will be used any time a splash or spurt of infectious fluid is anticipated during a procedure or activity.
CPR shields shall be used any time mouth-to-mouth contact is necessary for an emergency procedure.
Sanitizer gel shall always be used before and after any invasive procedure, including injections.
Any garments (such as uniforms, personal clothing, etc) penetrated by blood or other infectious materials will be removed immediately, or at least as soon as possible.
Work practice controls will be used to eliminate or minimize staff exposure. Where exposure remains after institution of these controls, personal protective equipment will also be used.
Work Practice Controls will be adopted by QBH as part of on-going Compliance Program.
Hand washing before and after using PPE. Hand washing facilities are readily accessible to staff. Hand washing sinks are located in all bathrooms, kitchen, medication rooms, and in the staff room.

Soap and water will be used immediately following any contact of body areas with blood or any other infectious materials and immediately after removing gloves. Mucous membranes will be flushed with water.

Contaminated reusable sharps are placed in appropriate sharps containers immediately after use and Contaminated needles and other contaminated sharps are not reused, recapped, bent or needles removed. Containers are puncture resistant, labeled and color-coded, leak proof on the sides and bottom and closable. Contaminated sharps containers are easily accessible and located close to the immediate area where sharps are used.  Containers are located in med carts, ICC area and any other area that is needed.
Consumer or staff food or meals are not to be kept in refrigerators, freezers or countertops or other storage areas where consumer blood or other potentially infectious materials could be stored.

Eating, drinking, smoking, or applying of cosmetics and/or handling of contact lenses are prohibited in the work areas where there is reasonable likelihood of occupational exposure to blood borne pathogens or other potentially infectious materials.
Specimens such as blood, urine, etc, are placed in designated leak proof containers, labeled properly for handling, storage and transport.

In some cases, blood borne pathogen infectious materials will have to be doubled bagged or double containers used. If an outside puncture of the container of a specimen occurs, the container is then placed within another leak proof container for further handling and storage. The second container must also be leak proof and puncture-resistant.

Labels and signs will be used too prevent exposure to blood borne pathogens. For staff the most obvious warning of possible exposure to blood borne pathogens are biohazard labels. Pronghorn Psychiatry has instituted a     comprehensive biohazard warning-label program. Items in the organization that are labeled will include but not be limited to the following:
Containers of regulated waste
Sharps disposal containers
The use of red color-coded containers will be utilized for biohazard waste.

Establishment of appropriate Engineering Controls to eliminate or minimize staff exposure. Engineering Controls is one of the key aspects of the QBH Exposure Control Plan. When necessary, personal protective equipment deemed appropriate will also be used.

QBH uses appropriate engineering controls to minimize staff contact with blood borne pathogens and other infectious materials. Annually QBH reviews the status of areas where Engineering Controls are currently employed, such as hand washing facilities, sanitizer gel, gloves, CPR shields, PPE, sharps containers which are puncture resistant, leak-proof and labeled with biohazard warning labels, personal protective equipment and specimen containers to name a few.

Part of the Exposure Control Plan is to maintain a clean and sanitary organization. To facilitate this housekeeping/laundry will have a schedule for routine periodic cleaning and a schedule for decontamination of infected areas.
As part of the decontamination schedule all equipment and services are cleaned and decontaminated after contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials.

This would include but not be limited to after any spill or blood or infectious materials, immediately when surfaces are contaminated, after completion of medical procedures, at the end of a work shift, after any damaged or broken
equipment (broken glass, etc.).
Hepatitis B Vaccinations and Post-Exposure Evaluation and Follow-Up:

The Organization will make available the hepatitis B vaccine, within 10 working days of assignment, to all staff that has occupational exposure, and post-exposure evaluation and follow-up to all staff who have had an exposure incident at no cost to the staff. (Refer to Hepatitis B Vaccination policy and procedure.)
The employer will establish and maintain an accurate record for each staff with occupational exposure. This record will include:
The name and the social security number of the staff.
A copy of the staff’s hepatitis B vaccination status including the dates of all the Hepatitis B vaccinations, and any medical records relative to the staff’s ability to receive vaccination.
A copy of all results of examinations, medical testing, and follow-up procedures.
The employer’s copy of the healthcare professional’s written opinion.
A copy of the information provided to the healthcare professional.
The employer shall oversee that staff medical records are:
Kept confidential.
Not disclosed or reported without the staff’s express written consent to any person within or outside the workplace except as required by this section or as may be required by law.
The employer shall maintain the records for at least the duration of employment plus 30 years in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.20.
Training records shall include the following information:
The dates of the training sessions;
The contents or a summary of the training sessions;
The names and qualifications of persons conducting the training; and
The names and job titles of all persons attending the training sessions.
Training records shall be maintained for 3 years from the date on which the training occurred.
Training for staff will include the following:
The OSHA standard for Blood borne Pathogens.
Epidemiology and symptomatology of blood borne diseases.
Modes of transmission of blood borne pathogens.
This Exposure Control Policy, i.e. points of the plan, lines of responsibility, how the plan will be implemented, etc.
Procedures that might cause exposure to blood or other potentially infectious materials at this organization.
Control methods which will be used to control exposure to blood or other potentially infectious materials.
Personal protective equipment available and who should be contacted concerning:
Post Exposure evaluation and follow-up.
Signs and labels used at the organization.
Hepatitis B vaccine program.
All staff will receive annual refresher training.
Training materials are located in the nurse’s office.
The Infection Control Practitioner will maintain all records required by the OSHA standard.

This policy will be reviewed annually (once yearly every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) by the Infection Control Coordinator and revised as needed and submitted to the Medical Executive Committee for approved.

sections.title: QBH MAT Fire Extinguisher Testing and Maintenance.policy FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Quality behavioral Health (QBH) provides for patient and staff safety by establishing mechanisms to minimize risk.

The Safety Officer or designee, shall inspect each portable fire extinguisher on a monthly basis and document findings on the Maintenance Log (available from the Office Manager or from the Administrative Assistant..

To inspect fire extinguisher, visually assess that: 1) the pin is secure and has not been removed; 2) that the extinguisher is fully charged (arrow is in the green); 3) that the hose is not damaged and is in good shape; 4) that the extinguisher is properly mounted; 5) that the instructions are legible; and 6) there is evidence/documentation that the annual external maintenance has been done.

The annual inspection and maintenance will be performed by a licensed professionally qualified technician. A contract should be initiated with the nearest Fire Equipment Company to inspect and recharge, if necessary.

Any discharged fire extinguishers must be recharged as soon as possible	after discharge, if it is a rechargeable type. It the extinguisher is a disposable unit it should be discarded and replaced immediately.
In extreme instances the local Fire Chief may do the annual inspection of any portable fire extinguishers and record the inspection on the attached inspection tag.

Inspection and Maintenance tags for fire extinguishers can be obtained from any Fire Equipment Company.  Alternatively an Inspection and Maintenance Log (must be posted near each extinguisher) is kept and documented by the Fire Equipment Company.

The monthly inspections by the Safety Officer shall be documented and a copy sent to the Administrative Assistant at the end of each month. The original shall be retained by the Safety Officer for a three year period.

The annual inspection by an outside qualified technician shall be scheduled by the Office Manager. The Office Manager shall confer with the Safety Officer to establish the source for this inspection/tagging/maintenance. The original annual inspection report shall be sent to the Office manager and a copy retained by the Safety Officer for three years.
The Safety Officer shall review and, if needed, revise this policy tri-annually and 	submit to the Clinical Committee for approval.
