sections.title: QBH MAT Fire Emergency Drill.policy  FINAL 6 1

blocks.text: To provide a safe environment for consumer and staff by conducting emergency and fire drills as scheduled to train staff in proper safe handling of fires and emergencies.
To provide training for staff in conducting safe and timely evacuations.
The Safety Officer is responsible for conducting all emergency drills.
Drills in all areas will be conducted at least annually for the facilities are in use.
At least 50% of all fire drills will include evacuation of consumers, visitors, and staff; everyone in the facility must participate in each drill. All drills should be unannounced.
The scenario for the location and size of the fire, and the times conducted, should be varied.

The pull station should be used occasionally to simulate a real fire; however, the Fire Department and alarm company must be notified prior to the drill to prevent paying for a false alarm to the Fire Department.
Periodically, place the mock fire near an exit, thus blocking one exit to cause use of alternate exits.
Action at the Site of the Fire:
If a fire is detected, or drill instigated, the person discovering the fire will:

Alert occupants in the immediate area who are in danger due to fire or smoke. (If wanting to prevent alarming excitable consumer, the organization code word of "Code Red" may be used to alert staff members to the presence of a fire.)
Use the nearest pull station to sound the fire alarm. If no pull station is available, use a verbal
alert.

subpolicies.title: Away from the Site of the Fire

blocks.text: Staff responsibilities when the fire alarm or verbal alert is sounded:
If a fire alarm or alert is sounded while consumer and/or visitors are present, the staff escorting them or the staff present will be responsible for supervision and evacuation of all occupants.
Immediately hang up all phones and leave the phone lines open.
Close any windows.
Move consumers and charts to the nearest emergency exit.

Determine if anyone is absent. (For medical records evacuation, see Emergency Preparedness Plan). Do not evacuate unless there is immediate danger from fire or smoke, or if so instructed by the Administrator in charge. When instructed, evacuate to the designated area.
The designated areas by site are:
At the back of the parking lot.

Use posted evacuation routes and always move away from the location of the fire. Each staff member will have a piece of chalk in his/her desk. As they evacuate their work area, each staff member shall close and mark the door with a check mark designating that the office or room is secure.

Designated staff in each area of the facility will double check bathrooms, offices, and all other areas to monitor that all building occupants have been evacuated. They will turn out lights and close doors behind them, marking doors as they secure the area.
Remain calm. Smoke rises, so stay low. Always feel doors before opening them, and if they are hot, use an alternate route.

Staff that evacuates the building with no identified patient responsibility will report to their supervisor for roll call and duty assignment. Congregate in the designated area, leaving driveways and alleys free for the approach of emergency vehicles.
In the event of an actual fire, no staff or consumer shall re-enter the building until authorized by the Fire Department. NOTE: THE FIRE DEPARTMENT WILL TAKE CHARGE UPON ARRIVAL!

Drills taking over two (2) minutes must be explained on the comment section of the Fire Drill Report. A reasonable amount of time to properly conduct a fire drill will be between 1.5 minutes and 2 minutes.
Times less than 1.5 minutes (90 seconds) are almost impossible, if the drill is conducted properly.
Drills should be taken seriously and conducted in the proper manner in order to keep staff and consumer sharp and safe.
Drill times of less than 1 minute will cause the drill to be questioned by any reporting agency.
For all other types of emergency drills and evacuation procedures, refer to the Emergency Preparedness Plan for conducting drills and evacuations.

The Safety Officer will review policies and procedures annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) and make revisions when needed. Any revisions made will be submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT Hand Washing.policy   FINAL 11 12

blocks.text: Proper hand washing is imperative to prevent or reduce incidence of cross-infections.  Hand washing is the single most effective method of preventing the spread of germs.
Wash hand for approximately 10-15 seconds.
Wet hands under lukewarm running water.
Apply soap to wet hands.
Lather hands using rotary motion and friction being careful not to cause a breakdown of the skin.
Rinse under water.
Pat dry with clean paper towels.
Use papers towels to turn off the faucet and to open bathroom doors.
Properly dispose of used paper towels.
Thorough hand washing is required by all staff:
Whenever hands are soiled.
Before giving injections.
Before and after handling all medications.
Before putting on and removing disposable gloves.
After prolonged contact with consumers.
After handling contaminated tissues or dressings.
After contact with body fluids or secretions and broken skin.
After personal body functions, using the toilet, blowing or wiping the nose, coughing, smoking, or combing hair.
Before and after eating.
Upon completion of work day.
Thorough hand washing is encouraged by consumers who are trained on proper procedure during orientation and training in reinforced as needed during their course of treatment:
Whenever hands are soiled.
Before and after handling all medications.
After contact with body fluids or secretions and broken skin.
After personal body functions, using the toilet, blowing or wiping the nose, coughing, smoking, or combing hair.
Before and after eating.
A liquid antimicrobial soap will be used.  Bar soap is not allowed.
Trash containers will be strategically placed near bathroom exits for disposal of paper towels after opening doors.

sections.title: QBH MAT Hazardous Materials.plan  FINAL  6 17

blocks.text: It is the policy of Quality behavioral health, Inc. (QBH) to establish mechanisms to define, identify, handle, store and dispose of hazardous materials/waste in support of a safe environment.
Criteria were established utilizing state and local regulatory definitions and environment guidelines.
Materials identified for Hazardous Waste/Materials Plan monitoring include:
Infectious waste
Sharps – needles, syringes
Cleaning supplies
Insecticides and rodent control poisons
Any chemical or materials requiring a SDS sheet
Fluorescent bulbs
Batteries
Office Manager will keep a notebook of Safety Data Sheets (SDS) and revise the list as needed.
PPE are available at the facility and are to be used as indicated.
If necessary, the Safety Officer or Infection Control Coordinator will act as an additional resource.
Chemicals, cleaning supplies and any other potential hazardous materials are kept locked
in a storage closet no higher than eye level to promote patient/staff safety.
Universal precautions are utilized, infectious waste is to be doubled bagged and disposed
of per policy.
No chemicals will be stored next to food or near a gas fired hot water heater.
All staff will receive training about this plan at orientation and annually.
Staff will demonstrate knowledge on how to handle hazardous materials and waste as evidenced by their post-test results for this plan.
Evidence of staff education will be kept in their personnel files.
Handling and Use

Spills or exposures will be handled according to OSHA guideline; recommendations will be reported to the IC Coordinator. The exposed staff will complete an incident report within 24 hours of the incident.
Staff will report exposure to the Administrative Assistant who will share information with the Safety Officer and/or Infection Control Coordinator.
Any safety hazards may be reported to the Safety Officer without fear of   retribution by their supervisors and/or the Company.
The supervisor will assess potential harm caused by exposure and take appropriate actions as needed.
The Safety Officer is responsible for implementation, review of the Plan, and    follow-up on corrective actions taken.
The Office Manager will keep SDS sheets and all relevant data in a notebook for reference this will be kept in an area that is easily accessible by others.
The Safety Officer collects and reports information about the Hazardous Waste/Materials Plan and any follow up needed to the Clinical Committee (CC).
This policy will be trained on during orientation of new staff and annually by the Safety Officer.
The Safety Officer will review this plan annually and make revisions when necessary; they will be submitted to the CC.
100% of staff will be annually tested on the knowledge of Environment of Care which will cover the Hazardous Materials Plan.
Knowledge of Environment of Care will be indicated with a minimum overall test average of 90%.

sections.title: QBH MAT Incident Reporting.policy FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: The intent of Quality Behavioral health (QBH) is to provide a mechanism by which unusual incidents are reported to leadership in a timely fashion, and that all QBH safety, consumer rights, and risk management issues are handled in a safe, dignified, and prudent manner.
Compromise to Human Dignity/Human Rights – mistreatment including but is not limited to the
following: racist behavior, harassment, purposeful embarrassment in presence of  others or other
mental/verbal abuse; any intentional, reckless or negligent action or omission which exposes a
client to a serious risk of physical or emotional harm; neglect; exploitation (commercial and
otherwise); mistreatment (incited or encouraged); corporal punishment; unreasonable use of
force/threat of force; threat of transfer/transfer for punishment, retaliatory acts (against a
consumer); other blatant violation of consumer rights.
Misconduct – behavior that is not appropriate or is contrary to Company policy,
Company rules, ethical guidelines (staff), or Company behavioral guidelines
(consumers/visitors).

Occupational Illness – an injury that is incurred by a staff while doing a job-related treatment/procedure such as a back injury while lifting a heavy box, a needle stick while giving an injection, etc. This does not include communicable diseases acquired by exposure to sick staff, consumers or visitors.
Premises – a physical location owned, leased or designated for the sole use of QBH to conduct QBH business.
Property – buildings, equipment, supplies, grounds and like-type possessions of QBH, whether owned, leased, or designated for sole use of QBH.
Staff – persons who are under obligation to provide a service to QBH whether an employee, a contract provider, a student/intern, or a volunteer.
Visitors – persons other than consumers or staff, whether authorized or unauthorized, who 	are present on Maxus premises.
All staff is responsible for completing an “Incident Report” (see attached sample) within one (1) business day of any unusual incident in which s/he is involved.
Failure to report may result in disciplinary action.
Staff is encouraged to assist consumers in completing an Incident Report if it does not unduly stress the consumer, or if the consumer makes this request.
Staff is expected to use good judgment in determining if an Incident Report is 	necessary. In general, the following types of situations would require an Incident  Report:
Injury or Death such as the following:
Any consumer, visitor or staff injury on premises, or while conducting QBH business that requires more than basic first aid (excluding minor scrapes/cuts/bruises) or medical intervention.
Death/suicide of a consumer, visitor or staff on the premises, or while in the custody of
QBH staff, or on QBH business.
Any threat, with obvious intent to follow through, of personal injury to self (e.g. attempted suicide) or others while on the premises.
d.	Any injury (or threat with obvious intent to follow through) off premises, while conducting QBH business.
Consumer deaths  resulting from MAT treatment to include:
Drug related deaths
Methadone or buprenorphine deaths
Unexpected or suspicious deaths
Treatment context deaths that raise individual, family, community or public concern
Staff Illness
Occupationally induced illnesses of staff (this does not include communicable illness such as flu or colds, etc).
Damage to QBH property such as the following:
Occurrence that results in damage (not just cosmetic) to QBH property that poses a risk/endangerment to other consumers, visitors or staff.
Transport incidents including break down, medical emergency, or collision, in company owned or leased vehicle AND in personal vehicle (if occurrence is while conducting QBH business).
Safety or security breaches that jeopardize health or well-being such as the following:

Medication error or adverse reaction requiring medical treatment at in a health care setting.   [These events do not require Incident Report Form completion but rather are to be reported to the Clinical Committee who completes a separate Medication Error Form which is submitted to Human Resources.
Occurrence of misconduct, disruptive or potentially violent behavior by consumer, visitor, or staff.
Occurrence that insults or compromises human dignity or violates human rights.
Occurrence that necessitates a Police Report or Protective Service Report of abuse/neglect/rape or other event.
Occurrence that constricts or prohibits service from being safely  provided such as a security breach; bomb threat; violent person on the property; non-working fire safety equipment;
Physical plant disasters, such as major fire within the service location when consumers were present or which affect consumer service areas.
Consumers who leave treatment (AMA) despite the advice of Company clinical or medical staff.
Special considerations requiring reporting that may be unique to the MAT program include:
Harm to family members or others from ingesting a consumer’s medication.
Selling drugs on the premises.
Medication diversion.
Any other occurrence that is out-of-the-ordinary that administrative staff need to be informed of promptly.
If staff is uncertain as to whether or not an Incident Report is needed, s/he will ask the Administrative Assistant. When in doubt, write an Incident Report.

Psychiatric or crisis emergencies are not by themselves “unusual” at the 	Company. However, if the behavior is extreme (such as actual injury, attempt, or plan of injury in the presence of staff, or evidence of such in the presence of staff), then an Incident Report is necessary.
Completing the Incident Report form:
Write or print very clearly, with black ink.
Complete all sections with an answer or “N/A” for “Not applicable.”
Designate full names of staff or other persons involved.
Include behaviors and all relevant details.

If more space is needed, continue on the back page, or attach an additional sheet to the report with the page number and Incident Report number written on the upper right-hand corner. Sign and date each additional page, with a diagonal line drawn through any unused portion of the page.
Sign and date the report.
Attach any supporting documents needed.
Send the completed Incident Report (and supporting documents) to the Administrative Office.

If the incident is serious or crucial and demands extraordinary attention, the staff will     immediately contact the CEO, or designee, for problem solving assistance. The CEO will be alerted immediately regarding situations that are critical.  Critical situations would be situations of great harm or potential harm. These would include incidents such as:
Any death. Any injury that requires hospitalization.
A building safety issue that creates immediate jeopardy to the safety and/or lives of consumers, staff, or visitors.
Any situation that is extraordinary in its occurrence and/or that has drawn the attention of police or media.
Any situation that is extraordinary in its occurrence that needs the leadership decision-making authority.
Routing Process for Incident Reports – ALL INCIDENT REPORTS, WHETHER 	ORIGINAL OR COPY, ARE HANDLED AS A CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENT; INCIDENT REPORTS ARE NEVER FILED IN CONSUMER RECORDS.
The Safety Officer, promptly upon receipt, sends a fax copy to the Human Resources
Department and provides a copy to the CEO.

The HR Coordinator will promptly notify the CEO of the Incident Report at which a point a determination will be made of whether immediate attention to the report is needed or if it will be reviewed and then integrated with other reports for aggregation and trending. If the incident entails a sentinel event, by Joint Commission, CMS or MHHS definitions, a sentinel event process will be initiated (see Sentinel Event Policy).
Upon receiving a copy of the Incident Report and any attached documentation, the

CEO reviews the report within five business days, to ascertain if the situation was handled appropriately and safely. If there are any legal, safety, treatment, policy/procedural, or consumer rights issues, will take steps to remedy the situation, and will include this documentation on the original Incident Report.
Once the CEO has completed their portion of the Incident Report, the original is forwarded, to the Human Resources Department, where all original Incident Report documents shall be filed.
The Safety Officer will retain a copy of the Incident Report with other Incident Reports in a secured file.

After the incident has been reviewed as satisfactorily settled by the CEO, a copy of the Incident Report is distributed by the Human Resources Coordinator or designee within two (2) business days to the following for purposes of review for identification of other action that might be taken to prevent a recurrence of this type event, if possible, and for reporting of trends related to that function:
Safety Officer
Quality Manager
Infection Control Coordinator, only if infection is associated with the incident.

Upon review by the Safety Officer, the Safety Officer may make recommendations and initiate additional action, if indicated, to be included in the next Safety Report to the QBH Clinical Committee (CC)..
The Quality Coordinator will aggregate data on all Incident Reports, will review for possible
trends/patterns, and will report as scheduled to the QBH CC.

Upon review by the Infection Control Coordinator, when applicable, the Infection Control Coordinator may make recommendations and initiate additional action, if indicated, to be included in the next Infection Control Report to the QBH CC.

Each Safety Officer shall fill out the QBH Incident Report Tally Form and send it, during the first five (5) days of the month following the month to which the data refers, to the Human Resources Department. Even if there were no events during the month, the form should be sent indicating there were no events.
This policy shall be reviewed and, when necessary, revised by the CC annually and as changes are necessary.
All staff shall be trained on the Incident Reporting process at new hire orientation and annually by the QBH CC

sections.title: QBH MAT INFECTION CONTROL PLAN.policy FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral health, Inc. (QBH) will sustain an active system for the prevention, reduction, early identification and control of infections throughout QBH's facility.  Under the guidance of the Infection Control function of the Clinical Committee, the Infection Control Coordinator is charged with the responsibility for the coordination of the Infection Control System and is responsible for the following:
Establish goals for the infection control program, in collaboration with the Clinical Committee.
Integrate Infection Control with Safety and QI systems. Implementation is under the direction of the Clinical Committee.

Conduct ongoing Risk Assessments. Risk analysis is done annually and as needed, considering current or changing geographic location of services, community environment, patient population characteristics, and services provided, prior infection results of the Company, and treatment modalities used.

Conduct effective surveillance, data collection and analysis. Surveillance will occur for early identification and appropriate management of infections and surveillance of compliance with infection control practices.

Implement effective prevention and control processes. Supervision and management of methods that may require development, and implementation of preventative or corrective processes, policies and procedures, or protocols designed to minimize the incidence of health care acquired infections and to prevent, promptly identify and control the spread of healthcare acquired infections is provided via the Infection Control Coordinator with oversight by the Clinical Committee.
Supervise and manage patient techniques that require development and implement
preventative or corrective programs, policies and procedures, or protocols designed to
minimize the incidence of healthcare acquired infections.
Assist with development of staff policies and oversight of staff health issues.

Educate and collaborate with leaders for their participation. Infection Control information/education is provided to all staff at orientation, re-orientation annually, and as needed. Training aims to develop and maintain a unity of purpose and action within QBH regarding the prevention and control of infection.

Integrate efforts with community and health care leaders for community-wide effort particularly in the reporting of designated infections and communication or assistance with Company-wide or community-wide outbreaks.
Plan for infections that may overwhelm the Company’s resources. See Reporting and Disease Outbreak Control below.
The Company’s leadership will overs that:

An effective system for the maintenance of an environment that is directed toward the identification, and control of infections brought into the Company from the community, and the prevention of healthcare acquired infections is in place.
Involve medical, clinical, administrative, and other staff in a multi-disciplinary effort to develop a system meeting the requirements of accreditation.
Develop and maintain a unity of purpose and action within the Company regarding the control of infections.
Delineate responsibility for the various aspects of the Infection Control System.
Infection Control – Those actions that are related to the prevention and management of infections of either patients or staff.

Environmental Control – Those continuing actions that are related to the surveillance and monitoring of the various areas of the Company in an effort to prevent contamination or cross-contamination of the Company environment with potential agents.

Healthcare Acquired – An infection that was not incubating at the time of admission to the Company.  If the incubation period is unknown and the infection developed more than 48 hours after admission, it is considered healthcare acquired.
Community-Acquired – Any infection with obvious signs and symptoms noted upon admission or within 48 hours after admit.

The Infection Control Plan will be sustained in accordance with current standards and requirements of accreditation agencies, MDHS, WHO, CDC, and OSHA.  The Clinical Committee has determined that the Infection Control Coordinator shall devote at a minimum of 10 hours per month to infection control activities. Infection control cannot be based solely on a number of hours per month but is based on the amount of time it takes to do the job and must be looked at by risk involved, responding to epidemics of emerging and reemerging infections and development of an Companyal wide approach to reducing the risk of acquisition and transmission of infections.

The implementation of the system through the orientation of all personnel, the formulation of practices for the prevention of infection, and the placing of special emphasis on areas of need is the responsibility of Administration, the Clinical Committee, the Infection Control Coordinator, and ultimately all staff and patients. Through the Infection Control Coordinator, a system is established and maintained for reporting infections and communicable diseases to the Clinical Committee and/or the appropriate health department officials.

Current priorities for surveillance, prevention and control activities are determined by the Infection Control function of the Clinical Committee with specific input from the Infection Control Coordinator and Medical Director. Priority risks are identified on the basis of patient demographics and risks, community trends and internal infection patterns, and current scientifically sound risk reduction/prevention practices and surveillance methods.
The following risks are the focus of the infection control system currently:
HIV
Influenza
Coronavirus
HEP C
Priorities may be adjusted if changes occur that pose new risks to the Company.

subpolicies.title: GOALS   (Plan goals are reassessed/established annually by Clinical Committee)

blocks.text: The incidence of infections within our identified high priority risks will decrease from the average incidence of each in 2021. Continue to achieve a zero-percent in the number of exposures associated with the use of medical devices.
Attain at least 85% rate in hand hygiene compliance (see Goal 1 in Hand Hygiene Policy) among staff by the end of 2021.
Demonstrate an improvement of the hand hygiene goals #2, 3 and 4 (see Hand Hygiene Policy for those goals) as evidenced by improved results from the beginning to the end of 2021

Increase the number of staff taking the Influenza Vaccine yearly by 10% each year for the next 3 years to reach a 70% goal by 2018 and 10% each year thereafter until 2021 to reach the goal of 90% on the 1st day of 2022.
The Infection Control function of the Clinical Committee shall:
Monitor all investigations, control, prevention, and reporting of infections within the Company. This applies to both staff and consumer populations.
Develop standards for infection control and environmental sanitation and establish standards for determination of healthcare acquired infections.
Evaluate on a continuing basis the policies and procedures developed within the Company for meeting established standards for asepsis and sanitation.

Develop a workable system for reporting, evaluating, and keeping records of infections among patients and staff to provide indications of the endemic level of all healthcare acquired infections, to trace the source of infection and to identify   potentially dangerous situations.
Provide staff support for periodic statistical/prevalence studies related to Infection Control.
Identify a death/permanent loss of function associated with a healthcare acquired infection as a sentinel event.
The Infection Control Coordinator shall:
Conduct ongoing surveillance of infection, gather and interpret data and keep accurate records of all infections.
Compile and present Infection Control Reports to the Clinical Committee
Inspect the environment and monitor staff activities for the purpose of detecting infection hazards.  Monitor and evaluate compliance with standards set forth by the Clinical Committee.
Monitor and evaluate aseptic and patient care techniques to support optimum care.
Monitor and update all policies and procedures important to infection control principles.
Investigate all “exposure incidents” and oversee post-exposure evaluation and follow-up process in order to recommend appropriate actions to be taken.
Notify designated administrative staff and appropriate health department authorities of all reportable communicable disease.

The Infection Control Coordinator, in collaboration with the Medical Director, will gather data on geographic/population infection demographics and consider that data in relation to length of stay, intensity, of contract, and the number of staff to determine what areas should be monitored, decide on prevention and control activities and formulate new polices. This will be an ongoing process which is reviewed at least annually and any other time needed and presented to the Clinical Committee for decision.

The Infection Control Coordinator will regularly monitor key websites such APIC, CDC, OSHA, WHO, and JC to maintain an Infection Control System that is scientifically sound and current with best practices.

subpolicies.title: STRATEGIES TO MINIMIZE, REDUCE AND ELIMINATE INFECTION RISKS

blocks.text: Infection control starts with each individual member of QBH. When hired all personnel are trained in proper hand hygiene techniques, blood borne pathogens and proper use of barrier equipment. This is reviewed as a part of yearly continuing education.  For use routinely and on an admission status report, Nursing and Direct Care staffs are taught to recognize and document any signs and symptoms of infectious disease including tick borne illnesses, influenza and respiratory illnesses, head lice, scabies, fungal infections, open wounds, fever, redness, and swelling on the skin surface.  Any such occurrence is reported to the Nursing Department for evaluation and treatment as warranted.  An infection needing further medical evaluation will be directed to the Medical Director.

As a part of the intake process, each consumer completes a health screen which is later followed by a History and Physical Exam.  This evaluation includes assessment for signs and symptoms of external infections and possible internal infection. A physical inspection is done for external signs and symptoms of infectious organisms. They will be referred to their primary care physician for any treatment needed.  If there are restrictions to their participation in the program, the physician will discuss this with them and write orders accordingly.

Consumers coming to MAT from institutional settings will be inspected for lice and may receive or be instructed to undergo treatment for head lice as a matter of routine. Those consumers found to have evidence of lice or eggs will undergo, or be instructed to undergo, a follow-up treatment in 7 days.  Consumers coming directly from their homes will be inspected for evidence of lice and treatment given or instructed to be done, if necessary. During flu season (September through March) flu vaccine will be encouraged for all consumers admitted for treatment.  Documentation of vaccination, if given at the program, shall be documented in the MAR.
Consumers and families are informed of standard infection control practices and their responsibility in preventing infections. This is to be documented in the clinical record.

Staff/consumers/volunteers are informed of standard infection control practices and their responsibility in preventing infections and the spread of infections during orientation and, for staff, annual training.

Visitors and consumers attending the program will wear masks and be monitored for signs of illness at check in, by a staff, and, if any symptoms of illness are noted, will be asked to cooperate in their responsibility to cooperate with necessary infection control measures. This may include hand hygiene, covering a wound and may be asked to wear a mask if coughing/ sneezing is present.

A consumer shall not attend activities while afflicted with any contagious or infectious disease/virus, or while liable to transmit such a disease/virus after being exposed, unless the MAT Medical Director or other Licensed Independent Practitioner has determined, based on medical evidence, that (1)  the consumer is no longer infected or liable to transmit the disease; or (2) the consumer is afflicted with a chronic infectious disease which poses little risk of transmission in the public environment where reasonable  precautions are taken.

Consumers with contagious or infectious disease/virus and their families have a right to privacy and a need for confidentiality. Only staff members who need to know the identity and condition of such consumers to determine fitness to attend program activities or to provide proper health care will be given information concerning a specific consumer. This includes nurses and persons who are most likely to be called on to administer first aid to such consumers. Willful or negligent disclosure of confidential information about a consumer’s medical condition by staff members will be cause for disciplinary action.

Reporting and disease/virus outbreak control measures will be implemented in accordance with federal and state laws and Department of Health rules governing the control of communicable strains and other diseases dangerous to public health.

All consumers shall be encouraged to be in compliance with the state laws and regulations requiring immunizations against poliomyelitis, rubella, mumps, tetanus, pertussis, diphtheria, and hepatitis B.

Everyone, including physicians, consumers, nursing personnel, advisor/ technicians, visitors, and volunteers, are responsible for complying with the standard precautions and for complying with isolation precautions.
Everyone is responsible for tactfully calling observed infractions to the attention of the offenders.
Universal Precautions procedures are to be followed at all times.

All staff will use disposable gloves and masks supplied by QBH when handling bodily fluids.  If gloves are not readily available, any available barrier, such as clothing or paper will be used to minimize direct contact.
All staff will wear disposable gloves and masks if open lesions are present on the caregiver’s hands.
Any open lesion will be covered and the bandage dry.
Proper hand hygiene after exposure to blood or body fluids will be observed and followed by antimicrobial hand sanitizer.
Soiled surfaces will be promptly cleaned with soap and water and followed by a disinfectant (bleach diluted 1:10 to 1:100 with water) or by using a blood spill kit.
Disposable towels or tissues will be used whenever possible.
Mops will be rinsed in disinfectant after cleaning floors and stored with the mop head up.
Soiled disposable materials that do not require being placed in a sharps container will be discarded in plastic bags.
Cleaning personnel will be aware of the risk of exposure to diseases when handling any blood or body fluid and how to protect open skin lesions (gloves).
All sharps materials (needles and syringes) will be disposed in special hazardous waste container.  This container will be closed when ¾ full.
Antimicrobial gel will be kept in all first aid kits at each building and in all Company-owned vehicles for consumer transport.
Housekeepers will attempt to maintain an environment that is sanitary and promotes infection control standards (refer to Housekeeping Policies).
Continuing input will be provided into the content and scope of the staff health related policies and procedures.
Monitoring and surveillance of staff for infections or communicable diseases.
Providing communicable disease testing as indicated.

To obtain a 70% Goal of direct care/clinical staff obtaining the flu vaccine by the year 2018 and a 90% Goal by 2021.  This will be accomplished by a 5% yearly increase in direct care/clinical staff obtaining the vaccine beginning with the year 2022.
Task to obtaining the above Goals:
Step up training on importance of obtaining the flu vaccine.
Keep posters regarding the flu vaccine in all areas of operation during months of September through March.
Track and trend reasons that direct care/clinical staff do not obtain the vaccine.
Annually review all data to see if yearly goals are met
Reporting coverage levels of data to Quality Management on an annual basis.
Reports of vaccination coverage levels on different areas of the facility/categories of staff.
Use of signed refusal statements by direct care/clinical staff that refuse the vaccine.
Annual report to Clinical Committee and the Board on progress or lack of progress in meeting the goals.
Consultation related to the purchase of all equipment and supplies used for disinfection purposes and/or invasive procedures will be provided by the Infection Control Coordinator.
Infection Control orientation will be provided for all new staff.
Continuing infection control education will be provided for all staff/consumers.
The Infection Control Coordinator will provide ongoing assistance or consultation for staff/consumers as the need arises.
All consumers will receive age appropriate information about the prevention and control of communicable diseases, to include the use of universal precautions.

The Infection Control Coordinator will continually pursue continuing education to enhance knowledge/skills in infection control and best practices and will document and report this training in at least one Infection Control Report to the Clinical Committee annually.

Reporting and disease outbreak control measures will be implemented in accordance with the state and local law and Department of Health rules governing the control of communicable diseases dangerous to public health, and any applicable rules distributed by the appropriate county or city health department.

In case of infection that overwhelms our resources, consumers will be discharged. Additional admissions will not be accepted by the Company during the outbreak. The physician will perform a case by case review of consumers to determine risk versus benefit of discharge.  If risk is greater than the benefit of returning the consumer home, these consumers will be transferred to other facilities. (See Pandemic Plan).
The Infection Control Coordinator will investigate and suggest corrective actions if needed.
The Infection Control Coordinator will give periodic reports to the Clinical Committee and Board about the system status.

Policies and procedures will be reviewed and revised annually (yearly every twelve months plus or minus thirty days), or when significant risk changes by the Infection Control Coordinator and submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval. Formal evaluation shall include:
Evaluation of the degree to which program goals were achieved.
Changes in the scope of the program.
Any emerging/re-emerging infection problems in the community.
Success or failure of program strategies in preventing and/or controlling infections.
Any concerns raised by leadership, staff, consumers, or others.

The adequacy of resources needed and provided by leadership for achieving IC system objectives, including whether regular reports on program effectiveness were provided and timely, resources for information access were sufficient, lab support was adequate, sufficiency of equipment/supplies for IC, and whether policies and procedures were adequate for guiding program activities and methodologies.

blocks.text: POLICY:	INTERIM LIFE SAFETY MEASURES (ISLM)
Quality Behavioral Health (QBH) will provide a safe environment for consumers, staff, visitors, and property.
PURPOSE:
To establish measure to temporarily compensate for the potential Life Safety hazards that could occur from construction activities.
PROCEDURES:
In the event of construction or remodeling activities, the following measures will be
implemented as deem appropriate to the situation:
Determination will be made at on-set of project of feasibility for population
relocation based on risk factors and space availability.
Exits are to provide for free and unobstructed egress.  Staff will receive
training if alternative exits are designated. Areas under construction must
maintain escape routes for construction workers at all times. Means of egress
in construction areas must be inspected daily.
Unobstructed access to external emergency service resources.
Additional fire-fighting equipment and training of staff in its use.
No smoking within twenty-five feet of any entrance or exit of QBH
buildings or and/or construction areas.
Develop and enforce storage, housekeeping, and debris-removal practices to
reduce fire hazard to lowest level possible.
Increase fire drills to two per shift per quarter.
Increase hazardous surveillance of buildings, grounds, and equipment
especially near excavations, construction areas, construction storage, and field
offices.
Train staff to compensate for impaired structural or compartmentalization
features of fire safety.
Further educate staff on Life Safety Code deficiencies, construction hazards,
and interim life safety measures.
The Safety Officer and CEO or designee will determine which of the above
measures will need to be implemented for the immediate situation.
The Safety Officer will monitor and document compliance with the implemented
measures on the ISLM Evaluation Form and report to the Clinical Committee (CC).
Any construction activity blocking an important egress which would compromise
patient or staff evacuation that would be blocked for more than 24 hours will
require implementation of these ISLM and notification of local fire officials by the
Safety Officer or CEO/ designee.
The Safety Officer will train all staff on this policy annually and all staff will be
trained upon hire by the Safety Officer during orientation.
EVALUATION:
The Safety Officer will review this policy and procedures tri-annually and make revisions when necessary; they will be submitted to the CC for approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT LIFE SAFETY EQUIPMENT TESTING.policy   FINAL 6 17

blocks.text: It is the policy of Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. (QBH) to maintain, test, and inspect all life safety components in QBH Facilities.
The purpose of testing life safety equipment is to establish mechanisms to support the proper working order of all fire related devices for the safety of all staff, consumers, and visitors.
Life safety equipment – any equipment designed to protect consumers, staff, visitors, and property from fire.
Fire alarm – any device that will sound an alarm in case of fire, whether activated manually or by smoke and/or heat.
Detectors – any device that sets in motion fire control, such as a smoke detector, sprinkler, automatic door closer, etc.

Each building in which consumers are housed or receive treatment will have a comprehensive statement of conditions (SOC), available to JC, which describes the current condition of the building’s structural features of fire protection.

subpolicies.title: INSPECTION AND TESTING OF FIRE RELATED EQUIPMENT, SYSTEMS, AND COMPONENTS

blocks.text: The Safety Officer or designee shall inspect and test fire equipment according to these guidelines:
Signal devices – quarterly.
Valve tamper switches and water flow devices – semi-annually.
Manual fire alarms, smoke detectors, heat/duct detectors – annually.
Fire alarm pull stations are inspected by looking at the handle in the pull station to see that it is straight up.
Fire detectors are inspected by looking at them and checking that the red light is blinking every 30 seconds. Fire detectors are located in every department lobby and hall.
Audible and visible occupant alarm systems – annually.
Off premises emergency notification transmission equipment – quarterly.
Water-based automatic fire extinguishing system fire pumps – weekly under no-flow condition; annually under flow condition (by contractor).
Water-based automatic fire extinguishing storage tanks high and low water level test – semi-annually (during cold weather, low water level test monthly) by contractor.
Water-based automatic fire extinguishing main drain test – annually at all system risers (by contractor).
Water-based automatic fire extinguishing fire department connections – quarterly.
Portable extinguishers are clearly identified, maintained annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus twenty days) by contractor, and inspected monthly.

Standpipe occupant hoses hydrostatically tested – 5 years after install, then every three years (thirty-six months plus or minus thirty days), with water flow tests every 5 years sixty (months plus or minus thirty days) by contractor.

subpolicies.title: Emergency lighting – The Safety Officer or designee shall test emergency lighting on a monthly (30-day intervals/12 times a year or once per month) basis and document findings on the Inspection, Testing, and Preventative Maintenance Logs.

blocks.text: There is a test button on the lighting unit itself. When the button is pushed, if the light comes on, the unit is working properly.

The monthly (30-day intervals/12 times a year or once per month) test is to be conducted for 30 seconds and the annual (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) test is to be conducted for 1.5 hours. Failed tests will be documented and retest will be performed after resolution of failure.
10% of all emergency light batteries will be randomly tested annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) in addition to the normal tests.
After any storm or power outage, all emergency lights and lighted exit signs must be checked to see that the batteries are working.

subpolicies.title: The Safety Officer or designee shall test battery powered smoke detectors on a monthly basis and replace weak or dead batteries and document findings on a Battery Testing Report Log. ALL smoke detector batteries will be replaced at least annually and documented on the battery testing form.
There is a test button on the smoke detector. If alarm sounds when the button is pushed, the unit is working properly.

To remove the battery, twist the cover in a counter clockwise direction to expose the battery. Simply remove the battery and replace with a new battery at least annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus ten days).

blocks.text: Old/dead batteries are to be disposed of with the other hazmat materials.
The Safety Officer will maintain a manual of schedules and test performance reports for fire-detection equipment.
The location of all manually activated fire alarm pulls are noted on posted evacuation plans.
Training on operational use of fire equipment is provided to staff at orientation and annually as part of the yearly re-orientation.
Ongoing skill and knowledge is evaluated as part of fire drills.

The Safety Officer will review and revise, if necessary, annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days), or as needed when circumstances change. The revised plan and plan evaluation will be submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health (QBH) has designed a plan to provide a safe environment for consumers, staff, and visitors and to safeguard facility property in the event of a fire. It is the responsibility of all staff to help maintain a hazard-free environment and to be part of the team in preventing or responding in an organized manner to a facility fire.
To comply with state and local fire codes and to maintain an annual inspection record with evidence or problem correction.
To schedule and conduct fire drills on a monthly basis (one time per each month); evaluate each occurrence for identification of problems and opportunities for improvement.
To complete all sections of fire drill analysis monthly.
To conduct fire hazard inspection surveillance tours semi-annually.
To conduct scheduled inspection and testing and annual maintenance of fire protection equipment. Inspections will include monthly testing of lighted exit signs and emergency lighting.
To assess situations where construction may pose fire prevention and evacuation problems. (See Interim Life Safety Measures Policy).
To maintain a smoke-free facility.
To educate staff about fire prevention awareness and the procedure for responding to fire drills or actual occurrences in the new staff orientation program with annual updates.
To oversee that all consumers, visitors and staff are accounted for.

To assess fire extinguishers, emergency lighting, obstruction of sprinkler heads, if critical supplies, equipment and current documentation that has not been received by the Home Office was safely removed if possible.
To assign job duties during fire drills.
To evaluate the plan objectives annually (every 12 months) including:  scope, performance, and effectiveness.

The consultant will be responsible for assessing any new office buildings and completing the E-SOC.  The E-SOC will be turned into the Chief Compliance Officer after completion.  Regional Clinical/Administrative Managers will be responsible for submitting bids and turning the bids in to the CEO for resolution of deficiencies.
Mitigation

All staff members are to assist in providing for the safety of all consumers, staff, and visitors by following the direction of the Charge person. (NOTE: FIRE DEPARTMENT WILL TAKE CHARGE UPON ARRIVAL)
Staff #1- the person noting the fire will alert other staff and assign duties to other staff. Duties will include:
Someone to call 911 and report the fire;
Checking all rooms and evacuating consumers, visitors, families, etc.;
Closing doors after room search is completed.
Accounting for safety of consumers, staff, families, etc. that have been evacuated.
Shutting off gas lines if applicable.
Staff nearest the fire extinguishers is to grab them and carry them with them when doing room checks.
During any remodeling or construction that increases fire risk or impedes usual evacuation egress, Interim Life Safety Measures are initiated.
Preparedness:

Training: Staff is required to review the Life Safety (Fire) Plan at orientation and annually (every 12 months) and to participate in hands-on training and practice in the use of fire extinguishers, and first-aid procedures.
Fire drills and evaluations are the responsibility of the Office Manager and will be held monthly. Drills should vary in time, fire situation, and numbers of consumers/staff present.
Response/Plan Activation
If a fire is detected, initiate:
R - Rescue consumers, visitors, and staff
A - Alert others of fire and call the Fire Department at 911
C - Contain the fire and smoke
E - Extinguish the fire

All staff will assist to provide for the safety of all consumers, staff, and visitors by evacuating. (NOTE: FIRE DEPARTMENT WILL TAKE CHARGE UPON ARRIVAL.) Fire Department will determine when an all-clear return to the building can occur.
When a fire alert occurs, all staff is to:
Immediately hang up all phones and leave phone lines open.
Close all doors to contain smoke and turn off the lights.
Move consumers and charts (if possible) to the nearest evacuation exit.
Be prepared for evacuation but do not evacuate unless there is immediate danger from fire or smoke.
Fire extinguishers should only be used if it is possible to do so without excessive personal risk.
Evacuation:
When evacuating, use posted evacuation routes and always move away from the location of the fire.
Remain calm. Smoke rises so stay low. Always feel doors before opening them, and if they are hot, use an alternate route.
Recovery:
Following any fire, an Incident Report will be filed within 24 hours of the occurrence by the supervisor or staff who first saw the fire.

The Office Manager will complete a Fire/Disaster Drill Report Form indicating any problems identified and corrective actions taken. Forms are to be sent to the Home Office where it will be directed to the Safety Officer for review.
The Safety Officer will review drill reports and investigate, if necessary.  Reports will be made to the Oversight of Operations and Performance Committee (OOPC) periodically throughout the year.

All management staff will have overall responsibility for the implementation of the plan. The Safety Officer will review effectiveness of the plan and report compliance with plan objectives and performance standards to the OOPC.
The Life Safety (Fire) Plan is reviewed and revised annually by the Safety Officer and    approved by the Clinical Committee.
Performance Standards will be designed to measure the effectiveness of the plan.
Staff demonstrates knowledge of Life Safety (Fire) Plan procedures and the ability to
assume leadership in an emergency situation as evidenced by post-tests, answers to         verbal questions, and/or by performance evaluated during drills.
Briefing will occur in the event of an actual fire/emergency with the OOPC.
100% of Staff will be annually tested on the knowledge of Environment of Care which will cover Life Safety (Fire) Plan.
Knowledge of Environment of Care will be indicated with a minimum overall test average of 90%.

blocks.text: It is the policy of the Pronghorn Psychiatry to provide a safe environment for staff and patients when equipment servicing and repair are underway.

Appliances/equipment that is unserviceable will be removed to the appropriate storage until they can be replaced or repaired. Equipment or appliances too large to move will have a lockout device such as a tag or lock with a sign affixed to the disconnect switch on a machine or piece of equipment that is to be serviced or is malfunctioning.

The Safety officer will be notified that servicing or maintenance is needed on the machinery or equipment. The Safety Officer will list the piece of equipment on the Maintenance/Repair Log.  The log shall contain the name of the piece of equipment, where it is located, the date of notification that service/repair is needed, a brief description of the problem, and, once repaired/serviced, the date when the equipment went back into service (or if replaced, the date of replacement).
A staff member, upon observing machinery or a piece of equipment which is locked out to perform servicing or maintenance, shall not attempt to start, energize, or use that machinery or equipment.
When the servicing or maintenance is completed and the machinery or equipment is ready for use, the Safety Officer will notify affected staff that the machinery or equipment is ready for use.
Designated staff will remove the lock-out device and re-energize the machinery or equipment as needed.

The policy will be evaluated, reviewed and revised, if needed, annually (every twelve months or once a year test plus or minus thirty days) by the Safety Officer and submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.

sections.title: QBH MAT Medical Emergency Procedure.policy   FINAL  6 17

blocks.text: It is the policy of Quality Behavioral Health (QBH) MAT to treat any medical emergency as high priority.
Medical problems can run the gamut from relatively minor, isolating events such as a fall to the significant events involving respiratory or cardiac arrest.
Assess the situation:
If the person is conscious ask them to tell you if anything hurts.  If unconscious, gently inspect the person for obvious signs of injury.
DO NOT move the person (especially if they indicate any pain) unless they are in imminent danger of further injury, e.g., an approaching fire.
Call 911 if the person is seriously injured.  DO NOT hang up until the dispatcher hangs up.

You may render first aid, but medical attention should be done by qualified Medics.  DO NOT come into contact with blood, vomit, or other Bodily fluids without the use of Personal Protective Equipment. DO NOT provide or administer any medicines except Benadryl in the case of an anaphylactic reaction.  Once emergency personnel arrive and you have given any factual data they may require get out of the way.
Limit your conversation with the person to reassurances.  Do not discuss their injury if at all possible. DO NOT discuss the accident or what circumstances might have contributed to its cause.
After the person has been given first aid and the incident is over, provide police with any factual details that you know.
If the injured is a patient, staff member, patient’s family, a visitor or 	volunteer, immediately report this to your Administrative Assistant/Office ager.
Administrative Assistant/Office Manager, or other person who was present, observed and/or was involved, will fill out an Incident Report for any injury and forward to the Safety officer.
Safety Officer will review incidents to see if there are any changes that should occur to avoid any future incidents.

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. shall use and maintain its facilities and physical environment in a manner that is consistent with standards of service delivery considering the safety and wellbeing of all consumers, staff, and visitors.

To provide guidelines for safe, efficient and sanitary use of the physical environment. The Organization shall provide a comfortable, protected environment against the spread of disease and infection and be appropriately equipped by:
Monitoring compliance with all pertinent aspects of the Michigan Department of Health Services facility licensing standards and other applicable laws, regulations, and requirements.
Providing the availability of adequate maintenance and janitorial services for the Organization.
Maintaining written records of all inspections conducted and of the necessary corrective actions taken.
Controlling the purchase, storage, distribution, and inventory of Pronghorn Psychiatry equipment and supplies.
Staff responsibility:
Observe appropriate standards of cleanliness and safety.

Report in writing any problems or deficiencies in the use or maintenance of Organization facilities and physical environment to their immediate supervisor in a timely manner so that appropriate corrective actions may be taken.
Maintain a safe workplace environment by:

Keeping filing cabinet drawers closed when not in use, opening only one drawer at a time, placing heavier items in bottom drawers, not stacking heavy items on top of file cabinets, and closing overhead cabinet doors when not in use to prevent injuries.

Using handles/knobs when closing drawer/doors; using a ladder or step stool to reach high shelves; using correct body mechanics when moving, lifting, or reaching; having another staff member present to steady the ladder or step stool if possible; and asking for help when it would make the task easier and safer.
Cleaning up spills immediately. Broken glass or sharp objects are to be placed in special containers. Do not pick up glass with fingers.  Contact Housekeeping for assistance if needed.
Avoiding clutter in work areas; keeping floors and counter tops free from paper clips, staples, pencils, rubber bands, and all unnecessary items.
All furnishings shall be kept free from dirt, in good repair, and shall contribute to creating a positive therapeutic and/or work environment.

Entry to or exit from the Organization shall be conducted according to security policies.  Pronghorn Psychiatry shall be accessible to handicapped persons by providing accommodations that facilitate parking, building entry, bathroom access, and counseling area access.

All areas of the building shall be climatically controlled at a temperature of at least 70 F. during waking hours. The building temperature shall not exceed 85 F.  Electrical fans, except ceiling paddle fans, are not permitted. Ceiling fans shall have a regular cleaning schedule. The use of vented or open-flame space heaters is prohibited.

Garbage containers with lids are to be large enough for waste needs and must be rodent and insect proof. Containers must be in good condition without cracks, holes, and be leak proof. All food products and food containers will be kept off the floor.  All spilled food will immediately be cleaned up.
All trash is to be bagged and tied.  Trash is gathered up during daily cleaning rounds.  Bagged trash is put in city dumpster.
When lifting heavy objects:
Look over the object to be lifted; make sure it is not too heavy or too clumsy.
Stand close to the object with feet apart for balance; make sure footing is secure.
Bend knees.  Keep back as straight as possible.
Get a good grip and keep the weight close to your body.
Lift gradually.  Straighten knees and stand.  Use leg muscles.  Avoid quick, jerky motions.
When the weight is too heavy or the object is too bulky to lift safely, get help.
Pushing and pulling objects:
Get a good grip on the object; hands inside handles.
Keep your back as straight as possible.
Brace your feet for maximum leg power.
Bend your knees to get the best use of your body weight.
Carrying an object:
Keep the load close to your body.
Make sure your vision is clear and the load does not obstruct your view.
Don’t change your grip while carrying the load.
Face the spot on which the load will rest.
Safety Officer, or designee, responsibility:

Staff assigned shall maintain bathrooms in a clean, odor-free manner with adequate ventilation.  There shall be enough hot water for hand washing all day.  The temperature of the hot water supply for consumer care areas shall be kept between 90 F. and 120 F. as measured at the outlet.

Garbage and trash shall be removed from all areas at a minimum of every 24 hours.  Wet garbage shall be collected and stored in waterproof, leakproof containers.  All garbage storage areas shall be kept clean and free from insects, rodents, and dirt.  A contracted vendor shall provide scheduled, periodic garbage collection.  Contaminated garbage shall be disposed of according to Infection Control policies.

All outside openings will be protected against the entrance of rodents and insects by using tight-fitting, self-closing doors, and controlled air vents. blocks.text: Medical device – an instrument, apparatus, contrivance, implant including any component, part or accessory, that is:
Intended for use in the diagnosis of disease or other conditions, or in the cure, 	mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease, or;
Intended to affect the structure or any function of the body and which does not achieve
its primary intended purposes through chemical action within or on the body and which is not dependent upon being metabolized for the achievement of its principal purpose.
Examples of medical devices include consumer restraints, wheelchairs, and syringes/ 	needles.

The Quality Manager will be responsible for overseeing an investigation and reporting of any incident that reasonably suggests that a medical device or medication has caused or contributed to the death of a consumer, staff, or visitor, or has caused a serious injury or illness of a consumer, staff or visitor.

Staff shall preserve the suspected medical device.  The Safety Officer shall remove the medical device and impound it.  Place or cover with a plastic bag to preserve the evidence.  The medical device shall be inspected and a report submitted to the CEO by the Safety Officer.

subpolicies.title: Staff will receive training about this plan at orientation and annually.

blocks.text: Behavioral Management training is an annual requirement for staff. Such training will be provided by the Organization or acquired by the staff member outside the Organization.

subpolicies.title: Documentation of training will be placed in the staff’s personnel file.

blocks.text: Weapons are not allowed anywhere within the Organization. A secure weapon locker will be provided for law enforcement officers.
Identification of staff and visitors’ entry into the organization:
Signs will be posted prohibiting loitering, drug related activities, and unauthorized persons on site.
Visitors will sign a visitor's sheet.
Staff will wear identity badges for identification.
Visitors will wear a visitor identification badge.
Staff, consumers, and visitors are encouraged to lock their vehicles.
The following aspects of security are identified as sensitive and have specific policies and procedures for prevention, control, and response to breaches:
Secure management of all sensitive or confidential information.
Storage of hazardous materials.
Medication storage and control.
Domestic violence, threats and stalking.
Ask consumers about restraining orders or threats; staff has a duty to warn if danger is imminent.
Provide counseling that assists consumers to break harmful associations; help them develop
a safety plan.
Presence of gang members or drug dealers on or near the property.
Weapons and contraband.
Grounds security.
Locked areas including entrances and exits and associated key control.
Working with law enforcement personnel.
Alarm key pad security codes.
At determination of a violent situation, or threat to consumer, visitor, or staff, or of any other security related incident:
Staff person witnessing the incident initiates action, intervening early to de-escalate potential violence, if appropriate, and/or notifies the Safety Officer of the problem.
If necessary, contact local law enforcement to assist.
Place violence related information in the consumer’s record and help the consumer create a personal safety plan.
Require consumers to sign a no-contact agreement that forbids contact with a stalker or abusive party.
Assist consumers in obtaining civil protection.
Connect consumers with community services.
Weapons are not allowed within the Organization unless carried by law enforcement officers who have been contacted for security assistance.

Post signs prohibiting loitering, drug-related activity, and unauthorized persons on site. Some clients may be reluctant to break ties with substance-using acquaintances and may need the clinical staff’s encouragement and program’s rules to end harmful associations.
Authority for security:
If the situation is deemed to be threatening to the safety of consumers, visitors, or staff, any person is authorized to take immediate action.
If the situation is of less severity, the Safety Officer will determine actions to be taken.
If the media is involved, only the CEO may give out information.

Persons deemed to be “celebrities” or considered to be “very important persons” (VIPs) are to have their identities protected, unless they give permission to be otherwise treated, at all times. Confidentiality is to be strictly enforced. If deemed necessary by the CEO, a Jane or John Doe designation may be assigned to the consumer name on the record to protect identity. In the event of more than one record, a number will also be assigned. Only the CEO will have a list with actual names for the consumer records.

Contact  switches on the door of the opiate medication storage vault/safe;
A device designed to detect illegal entry into the vault (i.e., electrical lacing of walls, 	floors, and ceilings; sensitive ultrasonic equipment within the vault; or sound 	accumulator system); and

Holdup alarms in strategic areas (i.e., the reception and dispensing areas).

blocks.text: Standard Precautions combine Universal precautions with Body Substance Isolation features.  The Standard Precautions are designed to reduce the risk of Transmission of microorganisms from both recognized and unrecognized sources of infection.  Standard Precautions are to be used on all consumers regardless of diagnosis or presumed infection status.
Standard Precautions apply to the following:
All body fluids, secretions and excretions regardless if whether or not these contain visible bloody fluids.
All blood or bloody fluids
Mucous membranes
Non-intact skin areas.

In addition to Standard Precautions, Transmission Based Precautions may also need to implement on consumers diagnosed with highly transmissible or epidemiological pathogens. Transmission Based Precautions would include airborne, droplet and contact.
Running water and soap will be used to wash hands (refer to Exposure Control Plan, section 3- hand washing) for specifics for Hand washing as defined by The Hand Hygiene Policy.
Hands will be washed after touching blood, body fluids, secretions, excretions and/or contaminated items, whether or not gloves have been worn.
Wash hands immediately before and after gloves are used, between consumer contact and any other appropriate time as stated in exposure control plan.

Clean, non-sterile gloves will be worn touching dressings, blood, body fluids, secretion/excretions, etc and clean gloves will be put on before procedures, touching mucous membranes, and/or non-intact skin as in open wounds.
Gloves will be promptly after touching any contaminated area and hands washed immediately.
Masks, eye protection, and face shield will be used to protect mucous membranes of the employee while during procedures that might generate splashes of blood, body fluids, etc.

blocks.text: EQUIPMENT LIST: Tuberculin Purified Protein Derivative (Mantoux) 5TU, Tuberculin syringe with 27-gauge needle, alcohol and cotton ball.
TB skin testing is required for all new staff, unless the staff can provide proof of a negative test done within the last year.
Testing must be done before the staff is permitted to have contact with consumers.
New staffs who test positive will be referred to the County Health Department for a chest x-ray before beginning work the QBH consumers.
All testing will be done by QBH nursing staff.
Thereafter, TB testing shall be done annually on all previously tuberculin negative staff.
Any staff that allows their test date to expire will not be allowed to work until they are tested and the results are received back as negative.
Personnel will notify the Program Manager/Supervisor who will then notify the staff when his/her skin test is due.
Staff, whether new or continuing, that has previously been tuberculin positive and has had a previous chest x-ray shall complete a questionnaire to determine if they have signs of active disease.
If no indication of active disease, the questionnaire shall be filed in their health file and considered sufficient.

However, if the questionnaire indicates possible active disease, the staff will be referred to their personal physician or the Health Department for further evaluation, the results of which shall be provided to the HR Manager for filing in their health file. If indicated, the staff may be excluded from work until cleared by a physician to return to work.
Obtain history:
A repeat skin test, when the staff is a positive reactor, could lead to discomfort, pain, and possible time off work.

It is not known whether Tubercol can cause fetal harm when administered to a pregnant woman.  If a female staff is or believes she might be pregnant, she should consult with her physician before receiving a TB skin test.
Cleanse skin with alcohol and allow drying.
Inject 0.1 cc Tuberculin Purified Protein Derivative 5 TU intracutaneously into the flexor surface of the forearm about four inches below the bend of the elbow.

Insert the point of the needle into the most superficial layers of the skin with the needle bevel pointed upward.  If the intracutaneous injection is performed properly, a definite white bleb will raise at the needle point.  This will disappear in minutes.
No dressing is required. In the event of subcutaneous injection, the test should be repeated immediately at another site.

Staffs/applicants should return to have test read 48 to 72 hours after administration.  Sensitivity is indicated by induration usually accompanied by erythema.  The widest diameter of distinctly palpable induration should be recorded in millimeters.

Positive reaction: Any palpable induration measuring 10 mm or more.  Staff who have had prolonged close contact with a known TB consumer, or are HIV positive, will be considered to have a positive reaction at 5 mm induration.
Doubtful reaction: Induration measuring 5 to 9 mm.  The test should be repeated in four to six weeks at a different site.
A staff who has a positive reaction should be counseled, and reassured, and given appropriate literature to read:
The staff (if not pregnant) will be referred to the County Health Department for a chest x-ray and preventative therapy. If the staff is pregnant they will be referred to their own doctor.

Staffs that may have been exposed to a potentially infectious TB consumer will have a TB skin test administered (unless they are previous positive re-actors or have had a TB skin test within the last three months).  If the initial skin test is negative, the test is to be repeated 12 weeks after the exposure.
Exposed persons with a test reaction of >5 mm and who are suggestive of tuberculosis will be referred to the County Health Department for a chest x-ray.

Staffs with current pulmonary or laryngeal tuberculosis should be excluded from work until adequate treatment is instituted, and cough resolved, and sputum is free of bacilli for three consecutive smears. A written release from their physician will be required.
