sections.title: QBH MAT Transportation .manual   FINAL 8 13

blocks.text: The purpose of the Transportation Manual is to provide a quick reference guide to basic procedures for                  transporting consumers. It is the goal of the Agency to provide staff with as much information and guidance as possible to encourage safe, efficient and competent transportation. If the topics contained in this manual are                                            carefully reviewed, driver-training classes attended and good common sense is used, it is reasonable to assume we will meet our goal.

The Agency requires each staff member who will be driving an Agency vehicle on a regular basis to provide a copy of their valid Michigan Driver's License and a Motor Vehicle Report (MVR) covering the past three (3) years. These items must be on file with the Human Resources Department before the staff member can drive any Agency vehicle. Staff is responsible for providing a copy of their Michigan Driver's License on an annual basis.
Drivers must comply with the following requirements to be eligible as an Agency driver:
All drivers of Agency vehicles must be 21 years of age or older.
Smoking is prohibited in all Agency vehicles.
Food and beverages are not to be consumed in Agency vehicles.

Staff is not permitted to use Agency vehicles for unauthorized trips or personal business. If a staff member wishes to take a vehicle home overnight due to an early morning or late evening appointment, prior authorization must be obtained. Once authorization has been given and prior to taking the Agency vehicle, the staff member must sign an Affidavit stating the Agency vehicle will not be used for personal business.
Vehicle drivers must wear closed toe shoes. NO SANDALS.
Drivers must complete training in "Defensive Driving".
Staff required to drive Agency vans equipped with wheelchair lifts must complete training in "Proper Procedures of Wheelchair Lifts".
All traffic violations incurred after the date of the initial MVR, whether in an Agency vehicle or a personal vehicle, must be reported within one working day of the infraction.
Report all collisions (including scrapes, dents, and scratches) involving any Agency vehicle immediately.
Any collision of, or damage to, an Agency vehicle must be documented on an Incident Report Form by the driver and submitted to the CEO within one working day.
The Agency encourages vehicle operators who receive a moving violation to attend traffic school instead of paying the fine and taking points against their driving record.

subpolicies.title: VEHICLE SAFETY GUIDELINES TO BE FOLLOWED

blocks.text: Seat belts will be worn at all times by both the driver and passengers while in Agency or staff vehicles when transporting consumers.
Non-ambulatory passengers must wear seat belts that secure them to their wheelchair at all times. Wheelchairs also must be secured to the floor of the vehicle using safety straps.
Every passenger will be seated on a seat which is securely fastened to the body of the vehicle and which provides enough space for the passenger's body.
No individual may stand or sit on the floor when the vehicle is in motion.
Car seats must be used when transporting infants and small children. State law stipulates that children under the age of four (4) or under 40 pounds must be in car seats.
The driver is responsible for cleaning the interior of the vehicle after each use. This includes discarding of any trash left in the vehicle.
The exterior of the vehicle will be cleaned at least once every two weeks by the program to which the vehicle is assigned.

The driver will enforce the rule of no smoking or use of any tobacco products in Agency vehicles and no smoking or use of any tobacco products during transport of a consumer in a personal vehicle.  This rule applies to staff and consumers.

All drivers are to successfully complete Standard First Aid and CPR within their initial 90- day probation. Client Intervention Training (CIT) may be required of some staff. At least one staff member (driver of passenger) must have all three of these certifications when consumers are being transported.
Vehicle doors will remain locked at all times when the vehicle is in motion.
Drivers will load/unload passengers as close to the entrance as possible (i.e., curbside in front of a shopping center store) prior to parking the vehicle.
Drivers will always see consumers safely to the door if they need help.
Headphones/cellular headphones will not be worn while driving an Agency vehicle.
Cell phones will not be used while driving an Agency vehicle.
The driver will remove the keys and set the emergency brake before exiting an Agency vehicle.
Consumers are not to be left unattended in vehicles at any time; this is especially critical with children and at risk consumers who cannot leave the vehicle on their own.
The driver will contact his/her supervisor or the front desk staff if the vehicle they are driving will be delayed beyond a reasonable time.
All Agency vehicles must contain the following items before they may be used for transport.  Inclusion of these items in a personal vehicle used to transport is strongly recommended.
First Aid Kit.
Fire Extinguisher.
Flashlight.
Water, enough for each passenger.
Proof of Insurance and Registration.
Mileage Log.
Name and phone number of an emergency contact at the Agency.
Emergency information regarding the consumer(s) being transported.
It is the driver's responsibility to notify the person responsible for the vehicles if any of these items require                    replacement or repair.

A pre-trip inspection is to be completed every time an Agency vehicle is used for a trip. A trip begins when the driver approaches the vehicle and ends when the vehicle is parked and the driver walks away. The items that must be checked during the pre-trip inspection are:
Exterior damage
Tire quality
Fluid leaks
Windshield condition
Emergency equipment
Lights
Proper operation of gauges
Fuel level
Interior damage
Cleanliness
Brake test
Lift operation and tie down (for wheelchair vans)
Working heat and AC
Any abnormalities need to be reported immediately and corrected before you begin your trip!

For every outing which is not a part of the daily routine, such as a recreational trip of four hours or more, or for outings where emergency medical services cannot respond within 12 minutes, a record shall be kept at the Agency which includes:
A list of consumers participating in the outing;
Anticipated departure and return times;
License plate numbers of every vehicle used for the outing; and
Name, location, and when possible, telephone number of the destination;
A cell phone for emergency use only.
Emergency information records shall be available in the transport vehicle for every consumer participating in the outing.
Information regarding medication requirements and any allergies for each consumer participating    in the outing shall be available in the transport vehicle.
Authorization slips on each consumer will be available in the transport vehicle.

We may transport consumers from their home and/or program to a variety of activities. We want to make their ride safe, pleasant and comfortable. However, that does not mean we let passengers do whatever they please. If inappropriate behaviors of any sort occur and create unsafe driving conditions, you should not drive.
Often inappropriate behavior can be avoided by the use of prevention techniques. Prevention is defined as the use of non-physical techniques to stop inappropriate behavior before it occurs.
Examples of prevention include:
Approaching each trip in a vehicle as a "fun" activity.
Make sure climate control vents are positioned to provide the maximum comfort for all passengers.
Communicating effectively with the passengers.
For prevention to be effective:
Take the time to get to know the individuals with whom you work.
Learn to recognize the clues individuals give before an outburst occurs.
Be aware of the individual's routine and any interruptions in that routine.
Give positive reinforcement for appropriate behavior in the vehicle.
Redirect their attention.
Communicate clearly with staff and passengers.
Evaluate the environment. It may be necessary to make some changes: 1) Radio level (too high, or too abrasive?); 2) Congestion (are there items cluttering the floor or seat?)

Use positive statements: 'When you get home maybe you can go for a walk" instead of "You cannot go for a walk unless your behavior improves."                                              When appropriate, use humor to diffuse a potentially explosive situation.
Some types of inappropriate behavior that may be unsafe in a vehicle include:
Shouting
Hitting
Spitting
Pulling hair
Striking body parts against the vehicle
Suggestions on how to deal with inappropriate behavior:
If the vehicle is in motion when the behavior begins, pull the vehicle off the road to a safe area and stop.
Take time to calm the consumer.
Ask the consumer what is wrong.
Separate consumers that are not getting along.
Switch seating around (i.e., often putting a disruptive consumer in the front will alleviate the problem).
Ask the consumer to stop the disruptive behavior and give them a reason (i.e., "I can't drive while you are doing that").
PHYSICALLY INTERVENE ALWAYS AS A LAST RESORT AND ONLY USING APPROVED CLIENT INTERVENTION TECHNIQUES.
Seating consumers separately who do not get along.

Positive practices of behavior management should always be employed. PHYSICAL INTERVENTION IS ONLY TO BE USED TO PREVENT AN INDIVIDUAL FROM INJURING THEMSELVES OR OTHERS. Unless the danger of injury is immediate, physical intervention is NEVER to be used. If intervention is required, the least intrusive means are to be implemented. Drivers will be required to complete Client Intervention Training if it is determined that they may be transporting individuals who have a history of injurious behavior. Any use of physical intervention is to be reported immediately on the Incident Report form and forwarded to the driver's immediate supervisor within one working day.

The driver is always the responsible party in the vehicle whether the vehicle is in motion or not. The driver must be-in control of all situations in the vehicle. If circumstances create an unsafe condition, the driver should refuse to drive until the conditions are safe.
Remain calm and assess the situation.
Slow the vehicle down and pull it off the read. Consider the following when looking for a place to pull off the road:
Circle K or any 24-hour convenience store parking lot which is well lit, has a phone and plenty of people to help.
Location with a telephone.
Other parking lots.
Calm your passengers.
Depending on the extent of the injury or illness:
In case of serious injury or illness (i.e., broken leg, heart attack, severe bleeding, etc.), call 911 and render first aid.
If you suspect internal injuries, even though there appear to be no external injuries, you must obtain medical help. Drive directly to a nearby emergency room or call 911.

If the injury is less severe (i.e., a scrape or cut) render first aid, calm the consumer and continue with your trip. If there is any question about the injury or illness, seek medical help. It is better to be safe than sorry!

If it is necessary to visit an emergency facility or paramedics respond to your location, all available medical information on the ill/injured consumer must be shared with the medical staff. This information will be in the vehicle for any trip over four hours in duration.

Once the consumer is receiving medical attention, the driver must notify their immediate supervisor, Clinical Director or CEO of the situation. Be prepared to give a detailed account of the incident, including:
Where you are;
Name of the attending physician;
Name of the paramedics;
Extent of the illness or injury, and;
What happened before, during, and after the incident.
Wait with you passengers until appropriate personnel arrive.
Seizure Emergency
Remain calm and calm the other passengers.
Immediately pull the vehicle off the road to a safe area.
Ask other passengers to move away from the individual experiencing the seizure.
Unfasten the seat belt of the individual experiencing the seizure.
Monitor and assist the individual and note the length of the seizure.
Once the seizure is over, reseat all passengers and continue.
Document the seizure on an Incident Report From and submit to your immediate supervisor within one working day.

Each vehicle should receive a weekly vehicle inspection by the department assigned the vehicle. The Weekly Vehicle Inspection Form (attached) should be completed and forwarded to the individual responsible for repairs.

If a driver has a concern regarding a vehicle, they should contact the individual responsible for repairs and inform them of the concern. This information should also be noted or the Vehicle Inspection Form.
On the Road:
As soon as you are aware of mechanical problems slow down, turn on your emergency flashers and move the vehicle off the road to a safe location and stop.
Stay calm and reassure your passengers.
Assess the situation. What appears to be the problem with the vehicle?
Is it overheating?
Do you have a flat tire?
In the case of a parked vehicle, is the battery dead?
Lift the hood of the vehicle to signal other motorists you are having difficulties.
Phone the office and notify you supervisor of the situation. Another vehicle will be sent to pick up the passengers and deliver them safely to their destination.
If you are involved in a collision:
Stay Calm!
Reassure everyone.
Check all passengers for injuries.
If necessary, render first aid immediately.
If the situation warrants it, remove the passengers from the vehicle to a "safe" area off the roadway.
Do not remove the vehicle from the scene of the collision site if it is serious, or if it is a hit-and-run.
7.  Notify the policy and request an Accident Report.
Gather information from all other drivers involved in the accident, including:
Driver's name, address and phone number.
Year, make and model of vehicle involved.
Insurance Agency, including phone number and address.
Complete an Incident Report form and submit it to The CEO within one working Day.
Vehicle operators must refuel their vehicle when the gauge indicates % tank. This is the bare minimum any vehicle should ever have.
Vehicles should be refueled prior to picking up passengers. If at all possible, do not refuel with a passenger in the vehicle.

Millions of miles are driven each year and most of these miles are moving forward. Yet, approximately 30 percent of all collisions occur when vehicles are moving in reverse. Based on the high frequency of these collisions and the fact that all backing collisions are preventable; emphasis must be placed on safe backing procedures.

Collisions that occur when a vehicle is going in reverse are costly to any facility. While the largest of claims involves property damage, the occurrence of bodily injury is still quite common. This is certainly a major factor when considering why the total cost of backing collisions is so high. The element of risk resulting in bodily injury is present when any backing is done.
There are many hazards that have to be considered when backing:
Inadequate clearance on both sides and the top of the vehicle.
Objects directly in the rear at the start of the backing movement.
Objects that move directly in the rear during the backing movement.
Blind spots created by the vehicle.
Inattention of those giving directions to the driver.
What steps can be taken to prevent backing collisions? Most importantly a driver needs to be aware of the potential for backing collisions and to consistently adhere to the following procedures:
Don't back up unless absolutely necessary. Proper planning of routes and proper positioning of the vehicle can reduce the amount of backing that is necessary.

Get assistance to help guide you when possible. The driver should review signals to be used and know exactly where the vehicle is going to go. It must be remembered that the driver still maintains full responsibility for the movement of the vehicle.
Use all available aids. These can include mirrors on sides of the vehicle, rear view mirrors, reflections of the vehicle in windows of stores, and observation of shadows thrown by the vehicle.

When no helper is available, get out and walk around the entire vehicle. This "circle of safety" should be used to observe anything that could come in contact with the vehicle. Be sure to observe the areas above ground level such as clearance of the top and the side of the vehicle.

Back into driveways instead of backing out into traffic. This practice will give the driver a better view of children or other hazards that might be there. It also puts the driver in the position to operate with full visibility when entering traffic again.
Made sure the proper mirrors are installed and they are properly adjusted before moving the vehicle.
Backup lights should function properly. Not only do they provide illumination in darkness, but they also act as a warning to others that the vehicle is moving in reverse.
Back up slowly. Drivers should always back up expecting something will get in the way. Slow backing will enable quicker stops.
Roll down a window and turn the radio off so any warning can be heard.
Driving backwards can be done safely, but caution must be the watchword. GET HELP — WALK AROUND — LOOK IN ALL DIRECTIONS — GO SLOW

sections.title: QBH MAT UNIVERSAL PRECAUTIONS.policy   FINAL  6 17

blocks.text: It is the policy of Quality behavioral health, Inc. (QBH) to establish guidelines to prevent infections and to reduce or eliminate the spread of communicable disease within the Organization. All blood and body fluids/secretions will be treated as infectious. The Infection Control Coordinator shall be designated as responsible for monitoring the implementation of this policy.  All Centers for Disease Control (CDC), OSHA and APIC guidelines will be followed.
All personnel employed at QBH will receive education on bloodborne pathogens and Universal Precautions during orientation and annually thereafter.
To establish Universal Precautions guidelines in all work activities with any potential for exposure to blood or other body fluids/secretions.

Barrier supplies shall be utilized to eliminate or minimize exposure to or transfer of infection.  The general rule regarding blood and other body substances shall be:  If it is wet, wear gloves; if it can splash, spurt or splatter, wear a gown, mask, and eye protection.
Universal Precautions shall be consistently used with all consumers when there is risk of exposure to blood, oral secretions, urine, feces, wound, or other drainage, and tissues.

Hands should be washed with soap and water and/or sanitizer gel before and after direct consumer contact, even when gloves have been worn. Sanitizer gel will be used before and after any invasive procedure along with the wearing of gloves and hand washing.
Gloves should be worn any time that it is likely the staff will touch body substances, mucous membranes, or non-intact skin.
A plastic gown or apron should be worn any time the clothing is likely to be soiled by any body substances.

Eye/mask protection should be worn when aerosolization or splattering of body substances may occur. Procedures should be done in a fashion that minimizes the likelihood of splashing, splattering, or spraying.
Used needles, syringes, and other sharps should be disposed of intact in a designated puncture-resistant, leak proof, Biohazard labeled container.  DO NOT BREAK, BEND, OR RECAP NEEDLES.
All items contaminated with blood, body fluids/secretions, or tissue should be disposed of in designated red bag-lined containers reserved for infectious waste.  (See additional policy.)
All blood/body fluid spills should be wiped up immediately, followed by disinfection with a 1:10 bleach solution.
In the event that CPR is required, a protective mouthpiece and/or ambo bag shall be utilized rather than mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.

Should exposure to blood or other body substances occur, the area should be flushed immediately with water.   After an exposure incident, a confidential medical evaluation and follow-up will be made available at no cost to the staff. Documentation of the route of exposure and of the source individual will be made. (See Exposure Control Policy.)
Barrier supplies shall be made readily available to personnel. Barrier supplies shall be stored in clearly marked locations in consumer care areas, in all emergency kits.

In addition to Universal Precautions, airborne isolation will be employed if consumers demonstrate the following diseases: childhood communicable diseases, pneumonia, influenza, meningitis, tuberculosis, or HIV.

Airborne isolation involves the application of the universal precautions listed in this procedure. Additionally, any staff who is susceptible to the disease or whose immune status is unknown shall wear a mask.
The consumer shall be rescheduled for a time after the infection has been resolved.
Consumers with known airborne disease will not be scheduled for treatment until their infection has been treated.

The Infection Control Coordinator will review policies and procedures annually (once a year every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) and make revisions when needed; they will be submitted to the Clinical Committee for approval.

blocks.text: Quality Behavioral Health, Inc. (QBH) strives to provide for proper utility management during normal usage and emergency situations for all programs. Utilities being used by this Organization include electricity, water, sewer, and communication systems. Phones are the direct responsibility of the Organization. All other utilities, with the exception of the outside utilities, are the responsibility of the Organization. D.T.E/ Consumer Energy 1-800-477-4747 manages the utilities for QBH. A comfortable and safe environment is considered to be necessary for all of QBH’s facilities in order to provide services.
To properly identify any critical components that, if not functioning, can produce unsafe consumer and/or staff environment or condition.
Provide training for staff on how to handle malfunctions of utilities.
To establish inspection and preventive maintenance schedules (monthly).
Training:
Staff will receive training on the Utility Management Plan at orientation and annually.
Appropriate staff will receive training on location and how to shut off utilities in the event of an emergency.
Inspections and preventive maintenance:

The Safety Officer will schedule and record maintenance and repairs in the Utility Maintenance Log. Scheduled predictive maintenance and interval-based inspections will occur based upon historical Organization trends, public service Organization or manufacturer recommendations, and/or during scheduled environmental safety tours. If maintenance is part of the contract of a leased building, the contract shall allow for a copy of these documents to be available to QBH.
All battery-powered lighting required for egress will be tested every month for 30 seconds and annually for 1.5 hours.

The logs will be reviewed at least annually by the Safety Officer to identify any trends or patterns that may indicate the need for improvement or problem solving. Results will be reported to the Clinical Committee (CC).
All utility shutoffs will be identified as appropriate and posted on evacuation maps.
The Safety Officer is responsible for flashlights, including monthly testing and replacing of batteries as necessary.
The Safety Officer will notify all staff members of the locations of all flashlights at their work areas.
In the event of electrical failure:
Staff will get flashlights from the Safety Officer or the known storage location(s). Remember, building exit signs will be illuminated for approximately 1-1/2 hours only.
Staff will:
Calm all consumers and visitors.
Bring all staff, consumers, and visitors to one location at QBH, if appropriate.
Never leave consumers alone, unless unavoidable.
Report all behavioral problems immediately to CEO or Designee or Medical Director.
Turn off all computers to avoid possible damage caused by the power surge.
The Safety Officer or designee will:
Contact ____, maintenance, or the building management company, if applicable, and explain the situation.
Request an estimate be given as soon as possible on when power will be returned.
Give information collected to the CEO.
The Safety Officer, or designee, is responsible for any refrigerated medications or laboratory specimens, when applicable. An ice chest may need to be obtained.
In the event of water or gas failure or malfunction:
Staff that becomes aware of the situation should immediately initiate turn off of the water or gas at the appropriate location(s).
The Safety Officer, or designee, is to notify the water or gas company of the problem. (See appendix A for utility company information).
If a gas leak is occurring, evacuation should be initiated immediately. (See section on evacuation in Emergency Preparedness Plan.)
The Safety Officer will:
Contact maintenance or  the Building Management Company, if appropriate, and explain the situation.
Request an estimate be given as soon as possible on when services will be returned.
Give information collected to the CEO.
The CEO or designee will:
Determine actions needed.
Determine if evacuation or dismissal of consumers will occur. (See evacuation section in Emergency Preparedness Plan for sequence of events.)
Determine if scheduled consumers need to be contacted to cancel appointments. If so, the appointment person will be instructed to do so.
In the event of phone failure or malfunctions:
Staff is to notify the CEO or designee of the problem.
The CEO or designee will:
Contact the phone provider for landlines or the appropriate cell phone company and explain the problem.
Request an estimate of when service will be restored.
Give information collected to the appropriate supervisor.
Get replacement cell phones for staff, if needed.
Electrical:
After electrical failure is resolved, the Safety Officer or designee will:
Check all computers for problems.
Check all rooms for potential fire and/or smoke.
Report any electrical/electronic equipment problems to the CEO or designee.
All light fixtures and bulbs will be monitored to ascertain that they are working and will be replaced as necessary.
Water and Gas
After services are resumed, the CEO or designee will:
Provide for adequate air ventilation to rid the facility of the gas fumes.
Notify all staff of restored services.
Direct appropriate staff to notify and reschedule consumers.
The Safety Officer is responsible for the implementation of the plan, investigating problems and/or user errors, follow-up to see that problems are resolved, and reporting to the CC.

The Safety Officer will complete a plan evaluation annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days). The evaluation will include appropriateness of the defined scope, whether objectives were achieved, performance data, the effectiveness of the plan in reducing/preventing risks and events, and any changes in regulatory and accreditation requirements.

The plan will be evaluated and reviewed annually (once a year, every twelve months plus or minus thirty days) by the Safety Officer and revised as necessary. This will be resubmitted to the CC and Governing Board as scheduled.
Performance monitoring has been developed to assess compliance with the plan.

sections.title: QBH Research Ethics Statement of Principles.form  FINAL r 12 15

blocks.text: Research involving human subjects must conform to the scientific, legal, and moral principles which justify all research, and should emerge from sound theoretical bases or follow acceptable research design.
Ethical aspects of the experiment should be clearly stated in the research design at all stages in its development.
Research should be conducted only by scientifically qualified individuals. When appropriate, medical liaison or supervision should be provided.

Human subject research projects cannot be carried out legitimately unless the importance of the objective in proportionate to the risks to the subject. All proposed research projects should be assessed as to their inherent risks in comparison to the potential benefits to the subject or others.

Experimental risks that should be evaluated include not only possible physical harm but also psychological impairment to the individual subject or others. Special care should be exercised in experiments in which the personality of the subject is liable to be altered by drugs or experimental procedure.
The nature, purpose and risk of the research must be adequately explained to the subject.

Research on a human being cannot be undertaken without his free consent after he has been informed. The research subject should be in such a mental, physical, and legal state as to be able to exercise fully his power of choice; if he is legally incompetent, the consent of the legal guardian should be procured.
Consent should, as a rule, be obtained in writing. However, the responsibility for research always remains with the research worker; it never falls in the subject even after consent when obtained.
The investigator must respect the right of each individual to safeguard his right to privacy and personal integrity, especially if the subject is in a dependent relationship to the investigator.

Coercion must be prohibited. At any time during the course of clinical research the subject or his guardian should be free to withdraw permission for the research to be continued. The investigator or the investigating team should discontinue the research if, in his or their judgment, it may if continued, be harmful to the individual.
Experimentation should be planned so as to avoid unnecessary pain, suffering or inconvenience to the research subject, his family or guardians.
Approved by American Psychological Association

blocks.text: There is no visitation during Detoxification. Residential and IOP-D consumers may be authorized visitations by their counselors after being in the program for a total of 14 days (not including Detox).
No more than $10.00 is allowed in Detox and no more than $20.00 is allowed in the Residential programs on the person of consumers.

Detox consumers are allowed the opportunity to make one phone call at admission and one after being discharged. If you do not get through, you will not be given another opportunity to make a call until you have been medically discharged. Consumers leaving AMA will not be allowed to make a phone call. There is no exception to this rule. Consumers stepping down from Detox to QBH’s Residential program will have to obtain a pass from their counselor in order to make a phone call. Passes are usually issued after 14 days. Phone calls for medical, legal, and insurance reasons are the only exceptions to this rule.
Consumers are not allowed to fraternize with other consumers or staff members.
No loitering in the halls or at the monitor and/or nurse’s stations.
No loitering in other consumer’s bedrooms, you are only allowed to enter the bedroom assigned to you.
A clear visualization of your bed must be maintained at all times.

You are required to attend all unit activities (AA, NA, AL anon, Didactics, Group and Counseling Sessions) unless you have been given specific permission by the Clinical Director to be excused from a particular activity.
Consumers are not to leave their unit unless escorted by a staff person.
No sexual activities between consumers, or staff and consumers at any time. If there is any inappropriate sexual behavior all parties involved will be discharged immediately.
Smoking or use of other tobacco products by consumers is only permitted during designated times and at the designated smoking area. Any violations of this will result in termination from the program.
Do not take any food/drink out of the dining area.  Food and drinks are not permitted on the floor other than in the designated eating area.
Profanity is not tolerated, if you continue to use profanity after being warned, you will be terminated from the program.
Stealing, borrowing, bartering and gambling are not allowed.
Unauthorized possession and/or use of any intoxicants, narcotics or controlled substances will result in immediate termination from the program.
Consumers must follow the program schedule.
Consumers are to groom themselves at least twice a day (showering, washing up, brushing their teeth and combing their hair). Appropriate clothing must be worn at all times.
In the Residential program, consumers are allowed to bring up to four sets of clothing, two pairs of shoes, one pair of house slippers, a few pairs of underwear and socks.
NO shorts that are above hands-width above the knee, no see-through garments, biker pants, sunglasses, leather clothing, halter tops, muscle shirts, or silk shirts.
All beds are to be made before leaving the room for any activity.

Electronic devices are prohibited, including cameras, video or audio equipment, CD/tape players/recorders or any other kind of recording device, cell phones, or beepers. If any of these prohibited items are found in the rooms, they will be destroyed and discarded.
Consumers are not allowed to leave their automobiles in the parking lot or around the building. Consumers must have someone else drop them off.
Yelling or loud talking is not permitted.

While in Detox, all medications must be prescribed, authorized by the staff physician and administered by the medical staff. Consumers administer their own medications in the Residential program under the nurse’s supervision; medications must be kept locked up by the program staff at any other time.
Withholding medication, palming, stealing, or selling medications is not allowed and will result in an immediate discharge.
You are expected to tidy up the day room after each meal on a rotating basis.
Each consumer is entitled to sit in one chair in the day room, no propping feet up on the chairs or lying in the chairs.
Stealing from staff and/or consumers may result in an immediate discharge.

The consumer is expected to participate in the initial and ongoing assessment process, providing accurate and complete information.  The assessment process is a critical step in identifying the consumer’s specific treatment needs and/or adjusting treatment as needs change, identifying strengths that the consumer brings into treatment, and identifying aftercare needs unique to the consumer.
